item.description: This is a work of fiction. All characters, settings, and events are merely a figment of my own imagination. Any resemblance to people, places, or real life events is purely coincidental. The work is unpublished and incomplete — any unauthorized redistribution is prohibited, (kindly.) Copyrighted Diia Blood The following story contains disturbing topics revolving around CHILDREN, including depictions of the following: PHYSICAL ABUSE, DRUG USAGE, ABANDONMENT, AND MORE. It was happening again.Jane Patterson opened her eyes.And what she saw was nothing but nothingness itself. Thick darkness veiled the surroundings from all directions, and only one entity stood center stage: a gleaming, red bathtub. She felt her chest shiver—the slightly painful type of shiver."H-hello…? Is… is anyone here?" she inquired, turning her head away from the tub and checking for any possible reaction. "I'm scared…" Her statement was only met by its own echo. Though the scenery wasn't unfamiliar, It still gave Jane the heebie-jeebies. It wasn't her fault the only dream she had was this abomination.Standing in the void amidst deafening silence was something, but being in the same space as that bathtub, was something else entirely. It stank with ominosity, as if knives and hammers swung all round it, or as if touching it would poison her to death, or simply hurt her. The fear was as much instinctive as it was reactional, yet, it wasn't logical, as she had no real reason to fear the tub. With no desire to walk up to it, Jane decided to walk away from it. She moved a good five-meters and turned back. The bathtub was as close as it was before she had moved. Of course, she thought. Nothing new.But suddenly, an idea struck her. Jane was a tiny kid, not that she liked that fact, and due to her height, she was never able to see what was in the bathtub from the distance it was in before. Coming closer to it was an idea out of the picture; out of the room; and out the house, but peeking at what was inside of it intrigued her. She took a long breath and raised her body atop her tippy-toes. Right at the distant end of the bathtub, she saw what looked to be deep, blue water, and the moment that water reflected in Jane's eyes, something squeezed her heart like a stress toy. Suddenly, there was no floor, and Jane was falling at high speed.It was only then, when she truly opened her eye. … Jane jolted awake, her heart racing. The left side of her chin and the shoulder below it were completely damp in drool, likewise the open book in her lap. One of the lines was drenched, but barely readable: Big Bee wants justice. Big Bee wants honey.She looked around in a daze, seeing towers of bookshelves and orange stars made of glass. Did I sleep the entire night? A glimpse at the clock above the broad double-doors showed that the small, chunky hand pointed at IV and the tall, thin one between XI and XII. She pondered for a second as her brain ran calculations. Six… no, no… When there is an I to the left, you take one away… so four in the morning. There was plenty of time before the bell rang and the day began."Morning there, missy," an old man said, causing Jane to jump and fall on her side. The man croaked a chuckle and bent over his round desk, smiling to her. "You snored like a hummingbird," he said, his gentle eyes unassuming above his round spectacles."G-good morning… to… too, Mr. Angelo," she said, her mind attempting to imagine what a hummingbird was before she could imagine it snoring. Mr. Angelo drew back and disappeared from Jane's vision. It was best if she went back to her reading, but she wasn't that delighted to go through the book for the umpteenth time. She thought for a moment, and realized a possible solution, though it required her to use her voice again… She shivered, but stood up nevertheless, wiping away the drool off her face. She left her book at the floor, making a mental note to return to it later."Um, Mr. Angelo…" she mumbled, only the top half of her pale, ghostly face, half-obscured by black hair, visible above the desktop, "Is… is there… is there…" She was taken back by the fact that Mr. Angelo was reading his book upside down. "Wh-why… read it that way?"He looked at the book, back at Jane, then smiled, "Why not?"Mr. Angelo was always strange, Jane reminded herself. Back on topic, "I was… gonna ask. Is there anything you recommend?""Of course," he said with enthusiastic body language, "everything!""How about… um… something more specific?" Jane was not about read everything, unless that was a book on its own. She looked down for a moment, her pink slippers looked back at her with googly eyes. "Something… nice?" she said, looking up cautiously to check Mr. Angelo's expression. His optics drilled into her with a thoughtful look. She looked away again. "Y-you know… Like all the other ones I read."He sighed, "Unfortunately, you've read all those books." Jane heard noises of thumps and papers moving. "But how about this." She looked up and found Mr. Angelo holding up a book with the title The Adventures of Sherlock Holmes written above, and By A. Conan Doyle written below it. She knew this one. "It has… murder in it," she said."It's a fine book. Good puzzles and all.""I do not… like it…""It's a little difficult, sure, but—""I don't want to.""You haven't given it a try. If only you—""No!" she said in Mr. Angelo's face with loud enough volume to leave a trail of reverberation in the room. Upon realizing her ill-manners, Jane covered her mouth and looked down in shame. "I'm sorry," she whimpered."You'll eventually run out, you know," Mr. Angelo said with a warm, but firm, voice. "You'll eventually be left with nothing but the books you hate, and what will you do then?"Jane stayed silent at that. Part of her regretted asking Mr. Angelo in the first place.Mr. Angelo took a deep inhale, then a long exhale. From the corner of her watery eye, Jane saw his hand rise and point in a direction behind her. "You'll find a new batch of books below Saint Mathew's window. Maybe something there will catch your attention."Jane lifted her head slowly. Mr. Angelo returned to his usual smile, but she couldn't help but feel that there was a hint of trouble in his eyes. It was probably her that troubled him. At the very least, she would need to keep her manners in place."Thank you," she said with a nod, and he nodded too, before returning to his upside down study. … Jane found herself in a narrow passage between the far wall of the library and a soaring bookshelf opposite to it. High above, four stained windows washed the library with color—mainly a soft hue of red, which brought a feeling of tension and religious significance.Like how Mr. Angelo said, there was a pile of unorganized books below one of the windows, most likely Matthew's. She approached the possible pile of time-devouring entertainment and began her search on the floor. From books of languages Jane didn't understand, to books of topics she had no interest in. The pile was starting to dwindle when Jane found something fascinating: an untitled, leather-bound notebook. Who would donate their own notebook? Jane thought as she opened the cover to check its content. Jane Patterson… Like, Me Patterson? she thought, trying to comprehend what she was seeing. Such a bizarre coincidence to find a diary with the exact same name as Jane. The time recorded was also this year. Now much more intrigued, Jane flipped a page and commenced her reading. Dear diary, Today, a new year rolls in, and it also happens to be the one year anniversary of my stay at the Pittyfall House of Children as a foundling. My memory hasn't improved one bit. I still don't remember nine years of my life. I still don't remember who's my mom or my dad. I still don't remember anything. Jane's jaw was on the floor. I don't understand, her brain called out as all the logic units went out of commission. This month-old entry recorded what seemed to be an exact parallel of what Jane had felt that exact day. But that was absurd. There had to be an explanation for this. Jane flipped to another page and continued reading, her eyes mere centimeters away from the paper. Good morning diary, Alice Danger found some firecrackers, and from the sounds of the screams, it looks like she's terrorizing the other kids with it. Thankfully, she doesn't come to the library. I found a nice book called We Bumble Bees. It's so fun. I love Big Bee! No, no, no! her head was spinning, and her face was glued to the pages of the diary, so much so that it looked like the notebook was eating her. It felt like she was chasing her own tail, trying to find something besides the obvious. Her heart froze in time. It was difficult to breath, and though the room was warm and cozy, Jane was shivering. From a sitting pose, she fell back down and the hair that covered the right side of her face fell away, revealing a silver eye with an old gash going through it. It was a stark contrast to the eye next to it, which was dark. Her lips were cautious as they shaped each syllable of the words from today's entry. Good evening diary, Today, I got in trouble and ended up in the director's office. It felt like hours in there, and I ended up losing my favorite book today, We Bumble Bees. I'm so sad… The diary slipped out of Jane's hands and fell on her face. She made no attempt to pick it up, or any attempt to move for that matter. She simply laid down in silence, foolishly attempting to process what she had just read. Hours passed while she was in her diseased pose, not asleep, but fully awake.Were the doctors right when they said I've lost my mind? Or did this diary just predict the future? She thought over the entry: So I'll be in trouble, be scolded and punished for hours, and then my favorite book will be taken? This is the worst! But that was only if the diary is not some prank, which Jane believed it to be, as there was no other explanation.A bell rang in the distance, and though it was typically the most annoying thing to hear in the world, when its so far that it no longer scrapped your ears, it was surprisingly soothing. Jane wanted to sleep so badly, her conscious mushy and soft, slipping away into dream land. But Jane knew what she had in dream land. It was better to not doze off. As she lifted her back, the diary fell away. She pondered momentarily about what she would do with it, but she realized she didn't want to do anything with it. She wanted it to leave her mind, as it was already cluttered. She took the notebook and shoved it in the narrow space between the shelf and the floor. Out of sight, out of mind. When she walked back, she found that Mr. Angelo was not behind the round desk. … Jane was happy that her seat was located at the far corner of the classroom. If that diary had a sliver of accuracy, it would be favorable if Jane was hidden, especially when considering how well her gray attire camouflaged her amidst the colorless light surging through the windows from gloomy clouds.The yapping and barking of children were silenced instantly at the loud yank of the classroom door. A short, plump woman with ginger hair came in quickly, speaking in a professional let's-get-over-with-it tone."Morning children.""Good morning, Miss Mary Patterson," everyone said in unharmonized unison. It was always strange hearing that surname. A mother? No, just a staff member who gave their surname to a child who didn't remember theirs.With speed and elegance, she wrote the title Psalm 34:4 on the chalkboard and spoke to the children as if she had an eye on the back of her head. "Desmos, stop eating the paper. You will choke. Louis, stop laughing at Desmos and tell your sister to focus on the subject. Art class can wait. And Alice," she turned around and looked down at the blond-haired girl glaring at the kid next to her, "it's rude to stare. You're gonna make Dean uncomfortable," Alice made a huffing noise before she looked away dramatically.Looks normal… Jane assured herself. If something bad were to happen, it wasn't now for sure. As the class went on, Jane decided to immerse herself with the view outside. Dead trees and mud. That was all what the rusted bars had enclosed, that and the grimy Jesus statue in the middle. But behind those bars, Jane saw someone. A tall figure next to a sleek, black car. It was then when the classroom door opened once more. Jane shifted her attention to it and found Mr. Angelo."Miss Director," he said with unease and began whispering to her."Christ…" She clicked her tongue and went back to writing on the board, "Tell him the only thing waiting for him here is a beating."Mr. Angelo nodded and exited the room. Not a blink of an eye later, Jane found him walking up to the tall man behind the bars. That was fast… she thought and blamed her consciousness for dozing off. A small exchange later, and the tall man cupped his hands over his mouth and yelled."Hey, honey. Do not make me get a warrant." All kids crooked their heads towards the monotone, yet sarcastic, voice.Miss Mary opened one of the windows with a surprisingly strong motion. "I'll make you, jackass." She closed it and pulled the curtains down. Everyone kept staring at her. "Back to class—and, you didn't hear me cuss." That was met with moans and groans of disappointment.Well, that was not normal, Jane thought, but it wasn't her causing trouble, or being scolded for hours, or having her favorite book taken. Not normal, but good so far…And it was good all the way through, except for the end: class had concluded and kids were scattering when Miss Mary came over to Jane's table. No trouble… No trouble… she repeated in her head. "Mind helping me organize some papers later, dear? I just have a lot on my plate lately," she said.Jane barely heard her over the thumping of her heart. She nodded. As long as trouble was off-frame. She nodded obediently, and received Miss Mary's rough hand as it ruffled her hair. … Jane spent her free time like a pray in the wild, keeping her best to stay safe. Would the person she had just bumped into attack her and make a fuss out of it? No, but they did say she looked like an ugly ghost—it was an upper classmate. Would the floor that had just creaked under her feet break and cause her to go to detention? No, but it did scare the living daylight out of her. Was Mr. Carl about to grab Jane and beat her like he always did with the other naughty children? No, but he did jabber about Jane's tousled hair and her untidy clothes.This diary and its entry were getting to Jane too much. It was probably just a prank. An unfunny and cruel one. She was not about to let a stack of papers get the best of her. Her anger forged her motivation, and she stomped her way through the halls. Her goal: somewhere quiet, aka the backyard.As she reached last corner, Dean passed her, flashing a bright smile. It was only too late when she had realized that he actually said Hello to her. "Oh—um, h-hi, there…" she said, but he was way too far to hear her. Dean was one of the few kids Jane considered to be a good apple, and here she was ignoring him. Embarrassment swirled in her head as it slumped down. She only deserved to look at the floor from now on.After a turn, she was seeing surging light from the backdoor making the wood below her brighter each step. It was then when something rolled onto Jane's shoes: a green crayon. She picked it up and read the cutoff text Starlight Color Works (SPECIAL EDIT- in her mind. Nothing out of the ordinary, she thought and a rustle scuttled before her. She looked up, and what she saw there made her heart squelch. It was Alice. Her face was covered in green, and she was out of breath."N-no trouble, please…" Jane trembled.Alice's eyes seemed unfocused, but she saw them glance to the right for a split-second. That was where Jane could not see. She turned her head and faced the worst possible thing to see.Mary Patterson's a BITCH! was written on the adjacent wall with a radiant green color. The same crayon that Jane was holding… Immediately, she snapped her head back at Alice, but she had already ran far in the backyard. In a moment of complete panic, Jane wound up her hand and shoulder, ready to throw the crayon into the next continent if necessary. But suddenly, a rough hand squeezed hers, taking the crayon from it. Though Jane knew who that hand belonged to, she was still aghast when the face of Mary Patterson drew in front of her."What a troublemaker," Miss Mary mumbled, her eyes at the crayon.Jane wasn't even worth to be looked down upon. "N-no… It… I…" she shrilled, attempting to explain herself and failing miserably.Miss Mary looked at Jane suddenly and her expression changed in a way Jane didn't understand. "Wait in my office," she said before leaving.Jane stood still for a while, unsure whether to cry or fall down and pretend to die. She didn't want to be scolded by Miss Mary. She respected her, but now that she knew that diary was correct—that it predicted the truth, however painful that truth was, Jane didn't see how she could escape the scolding. … The familiar room felt suffocating.Jane sat on a rickety wooden chair before a desk with a huge pile of papers, a cup of coffee with Don't You Miss Sunday Services! written on it, and a bunch of pill packs with the title Headache Free - NO RISKS and a picture of a pretty lady with a set of blinding teeth set beside it. She felt her body with five times its typical weight, as if gravity was her enemy. Her mind was a collection of staircases and pathways that all lead to the image of how Jane would be scolded—insulted—humiliated. It felt like hours in there, the diary had said, and Jane was living those hours at the moment. Her heart was so jammed in her throat, she felt she would throw up at any point. It all felt sickening.In a minute or two, Jane would have to face Miss Mary's fury for what she had not done, and explaining herself, with her clumsy tongue and such damning evidence against her, felt useless. She was trapped, and she desired to escape so badly. Run out the room and hide somewhere, she thought to herself. Anywhere.The sound of a footstep suddenly slipped from below the door behind her, which did nothing but made her anxiety reach boiling point. Her main escape route was now blocked.As if her body moved on its own, Jane jumped off the chair and zipped to the next best thing: the office private bathroom. She would hide there until Miss Mary left, then sneakily leave after. It was no perfect plan, but it was a plan. Jane slammed her small body against the door as she missed to catch the handle multiple times. At last, she grasped it, swung the door, shoved herself in, and closed it behind her, making sure to click the lock. She glued her left ear against the door and did her best to keep her breathing down.A distant door swung open with a creak. Steps thudded vibrations across the floor. Then, a pause."She didn't come, huh…" Jane heard Miss Mary's muffle.Rat-tat, a postmen-like knock punched the air."In," Miss Mary said.Another creak later, Jane heard that familiar monotone voice once more."Got my warrant," the motionless voice said."Good," she said out of her teeth, "what's the occasion?"Jane turned around, discouraged by eavesdropping on Miss Mary when she was this heated. She studied the bathroom she was in as a distraction. A cracked mirror cabinet, an orange, curtained window emanating the fuzzy light of the early afternoon, and one, gleaming, red bathtub.A shiver jolted up Jane's spine and activated something in her head. Something that dragged her out of her body and somewhere far away, sometime far off. … Jane saw a bathroom—a cramped, old one. But not the same one she had just been in. A different one. It reeked of a medicinal smell, sharp and bitter.A dream? she thought, but it was clear she had no control over the body she possessed. This was a memory. A memory that was surging through a crack on the dam of her head.Besides seeing and smelling, she also felt things—intangible things. She felt oppressed and trapped. She felt exhausted and sickened. She felt something rattle at her wrist. It was a chain. She was attached to the faucet of the red bathtub that was full of blue water. She also sensed her clothes fully drenched in that same water. From the mess on the tiled floor, it looked like she had dragged herself out of the tub by sheer force.But atop all those feelings, there was one that washed everything. It was a searing, pulsating pain throbbing in her head. Unbelievably bad, to the point that moving her eyes caused it to intensify greatly.What a miserable place. What a miserable life.She suddenly heard that someone was approaching and every cell of her body screamed in terror.The door behind her screeched slowly, and he walked in. … Jane opened her eye, both of her hands holding her head. It was not hurting—it never did. She breathed deeply, her body shivering. She got out before she understood who he was, but she was very glad. She didn't want to see what was there, and now, she didn't want to stay here. She had to leave.She took one glance at the red shell of the tub before unlocking the door and exiting, her eyes downcast and mouth open. Not a dream, but a memory, she thought to herself."Jane?" Miss Mary said in disbelief, a letter in her hand.Right. Jane was trying to hide. She looked up at her, then to the tall man besides hers, with his purple eyebags and dead fish expression, before she broke down and sobbed. There was much inside of her, from her fear of being scolded, to that awful memory she had just seen. It was like she was trying to speak those feelings, but the words came out as cries and whimpers instead of eligible syllables.Miss Mary rushed in to embrace her. "Dear, what happened?" She sounded hoarse. "Why are you crying?"Jane didn't answer. She didn't know how. So she cried for a while until the tears dried up and she was left with only sniffles. One positive thing that came out of this was that these cries seemed to have calmed Miss Mary down, because it didn't look like she was mad at Jane anymore."Oh, taking care of your little dumplings must be hard…" the tall man said, "Now that the orphanage is closing, I believe the difficulty would be bumped into impossible.""C-closing?" Jane said through sniffles, "What does he mean?" she looked at Miss Mary with reddened eyes."It's…" she looked away, "It's…""Church no longer wants to support the orphans with donations," the man interjected, "I'm sure they have a real good reason for that.""And they do!" Miss Mary said confidently, "I'm sure they do…" her voice trailed off."Of course there is. It's called Godeyes. The cult responsible for the many recent goofy activities within the church.""You do not know for sure," she said and turned with a pointed finger."Of course I don't know for sure, dummy. If I did, I would've put them all in jail already. It's just a matter of time."Jane was beginning to lose the topic, but one thing concerned her above all else. "I-is the orphanage really closing?"Miss Mary turned to her, "Don't worry, Jane, I'll… I'll find—""Pardon me," the man interrupted and stepped forth between the two, "Jane? Like, the kid we found in the streets a year ago?" He looked at Jane curiously. "Right, Jane Patterson…" He then shifted into a more deep and thoughtful look."Mind shoving aside?" Miss Mary told him.He moved with no comments, keeping that same look."Look, I'll find a new donor as fast I can," Miss Mary said, "You do not worry—""Of course," the man interrupted once again, "how could I have missed this…""What is it now?" Miss Mary said, her patience running thin and her fist clenching tighter than ever."Honey, I believe we can strike quite a beneficial deal," he said and came over to Jane, "A deal that will surely interest you." Though he was talking while looking at Jane, he seemed more focused on something beyond her.Jane eyed Miss Mary with confusion and dread as she only imagined what his deal would be."What does your deal entail?" Miss Mary inquired, her eyes hostile.The man kept his eyes at Jane, mumbling to himself with a blank expression, "Seventeen milligrams per cubic centimeter was what the file had—five times the fatal dose, yet here you are still alive… Of course, how did I not think about that connection.""W-what are you… talking about?" Jane said as she stepped back. Something about the difficult-sounding medical words, the same ones she heard from her doctors, made her heart sink"Speak up, and to me," Miss Mary stepped in between the two.The man sighed and rubbed his eyes with an index and a thumb, his purple eyebags flexing with the friction. "I want the small Patterson to help me, as I believe her to be associated with Godeyes, and I'll provide—""Wha—" Marry spat, flabbergasted, "you can't be real. She's just a kid!""My evidence are absolute. She can be a valuable asset to my investigation.""Don't you dare call her an asset, you lifeless germ" Miss Mary growled, "and you'd have to take her out of my dead, cold, arms."A sense of warmth washed over Jane. Miss Mary would go this far for me? she asked herself, but before she felt any flattery by such remarks, she sensed a heavy shift in the air as the man raised three, tall, and bruised fingers."Three months," he said."Pardon?""I can get the church to extend their donations by three months. That is my offering.""I… I don't recall you having any catholic significance—just, how exactly are you planning to get that?""I am in no need to be holy," he reached his hand below the edge of his trench coat, revealing a polished, brass shield clipped to the dark fabric above his heart, "to be convincing," he flicked his nail against the PITTYFALL POLICE engraving and it dinged distinctly.An avalanche of silence buried the room. "J-Jane…?" Miss Mary said shakily and looked back with most horrifying of expressions: it was that of a pitiful implore.Jane shook her head almost immediately and hid behind the desk. Her heartbeats were banging at her ribcage."I... I d-don't remember any… anything!" Jane managed, and she was mostly truthful. That memory that had splashed in her mind not an hour ago was useless compared to the years she had lost. She still had no idea who her parents were, where she used to live, or how she lost the sight of her right eye."I will help you remember," the man said with ease, as if what he was saying was the easiest thing in the world."Jane, dear…" Miss Mary began, her voice soothing, yet wavering, "I'm with you here—really! But without the church's support, we'll be out of food in less than a week."Nope. Nope. Nope. Not happening. Godeyes? Police? Jane wanted none of that. Oh, how she we wished to read her favorite books at this moment, far away in the peaceful library. She would be a good girl this time. She wouldn't complain. And she wouldn't open that wretched, wretched, WRETCHED diary ever again. This was all its fault. It had to be."I promise you," Miss Mary continued, her desperate voice ripping apart Jane from the inside, "I'll find another donor if it's the last thing I'll do, and as soon as that happens, you won't be in need to help this schmuck anymore!"Jane felt her determination faltering. It wasn't like she didn't want to help Miss Mary, it was that she was scared. But her desire to payback Miss Mary for all of what she had done was almost as strong."Jane…? …I see," Miss Mary said, and Jane heard her turn around.Smacking her forehead, Jane pushed herself onto the light and away from the concealment of the desk. She kept her head low, her one functional eye studying the extended shadows of the two adults before her. They were as still as ice. She waited a second, hoping for a miracle to happen. An angel full of pity. A demon that ends misery.Nothing.Jane wanted to cry, but she was out of tears for the day. She nodded her head and whispered, "I can do it," hoping the two might not hear her. Her hopes were dismissed quickly as Miss Mary's short shadow swooped in and engulfed Jane in a hug. Unlike the last one, though, this was dry. No warmth radiated from it."Seems like a deal," the man said simply."Thank you," Miss Mary said to Jane's ear. "Thank you," she repeated it, much deeply. … It was after classes when Jane had a sudden urge to go reading. Forget what happened, and read. She got in the library, and went to her favorite spot to continue reading We Bumble bees. But the book wasn't in its usual place, slotted between Steven Planet and The Crow House.Then it hit her. She had put it on the floor before she asked Mr. Angelo about a new book, and before she found that… diary. I ended up losing my favorite book today, We Bumble Bees, it said, but it didn't say how she lost it. She instantly assumed it was as a result of the scolding. She looked around and saw that Mr. Angelo was not behind his round desk, nor near any of the shelves.The book had disappeared even though Jane wasn't scolded or punished for anything. If we reconstruct the scene without Jane hiding in the bathroom, would she have been scolded to begin with? Was Miss Mary even mad at her in the first place?Jane sat on the cold floor, leaned against the uneven surface of the shelf, and brought her knees to her chest. She closed her eyes and thought deeply.Today, I got in trouble, the diary had written, and that did happen. Jane was caught red-handed in the crime scene. But when Miss Mary took the crayon out of Jane's hand, she wasn't angerly looking at her saying What a troublemaker. When she did look, she wasn't mad. It was strange, because only now was Jane able to understand that the expression Miss Mary had at that moment was of concern and politeness, of a person who was troubling someone, not being troubled.If that was the case, why did she ask Jane to come to her office? And as soon as the question came out of Jane's mind, a picture appeared in her head: a mountain of papers with pens and coffee mugs and headache-free-no-risks-involved pills scattered around it on a desktop. Mind helping me organize some papers later, dear? Miss Mary had asked. Of course. It felt like hours, was written in the diary, and that was because organizing that mess would've felt like hours.The diary and its foretelling entry was accurate beyond what Jane had imagined, but not to a full extent. It had nothing to do with the tall man nor his deal. It changed because Jane morphed the entry into something it wasn't. She morphed it into a nightmare, then attempted to escape from the nightmare, which had caused fate to punish her, causing things to diverge.But that was silly. Fate punishing a ten-or-so-year-old girl for being a little scared? No, Jane was clearly overthinking things. She made honest mistakes due to the unclarity and vagueness of the diary, and all it did was mess with her head.Disappointed that she hadn't found any ground-breaking discoveries, Jane took out The Crow House and began reading, speeding the clock forward in time.Later that day at night, Jane asked Mr. Angelo and found that he put the book in one of his drawers. Again, just a set of inconvenient misunderstandings. Nothing more. …The next day, Jane was having lunch at an empty table in the noisy dining hall of the orphanage. She looked down at her half-finished serving of mashed potatoes, sinister-looking cabbage, and sludge of beans, as whatever was in her mouth squelched down with the force of her teeth. She swallowed. I thought cooked air was a joke, she thought, tempted to use her knife and fork to take piece of air and compare its taste to her food. If this was the so-called food Miss Mary spoke of, then maybe not having it would be a blessing. Then again, she was only using the food as an example. There were probably many other expenses that an orphanage required."Done eating, Patterson?" a craggy voice came from where her vision didn't work."Ueh!" Jane shrieked a strange voice and hopped a seat in the opposite direction.The man, the same policeman from yesterday, looked at Jane dully, as if he's been doing so for the past 20 minutes. He attempted to morph his lips in a shape of a smile, but it looked more like he needed to pee, "Nice to meet you too.""Miss Mary… wh-where is she?""Busy."Was she already searching for another donor?"What do you want… from me?" Jane asked gently. Without Miss Mary, she had no protection from the bear, and worst of all, she had no idea what the bear will do."You've been to the Oddmoor Psychiatric hospital, I presume."Jane nodded. She hated that place."Well," he stood up, "we'll go pay them a visit. Now follow me.""But, but, the doctors… they're—""We're not visiting the doctors. But because…This feels wrong, her heart said.In fact, all of it felt so wrong.Jane truly no clue why her heart said one thing, and her mind said another. But in the end, Jane was a heart person, and so she followed it. Kept silence until Alice sounded asleep and missed her one chance to break the diary's entry.But it felt right.Jane slowly rose, opened her curtain to reveal the midnight moon, and brought out the diary from below the mattress.Giving Alice one last check, Jane opened the diary to the entry of February 6th. Today, I found Alice by the arched tree in the backyard near the forest. After gathering all my courage, I tried to talk to her. I tried to apologize for what I caused.It didn't work. She didn't want my apology. But not just that, she didn't want to see my face at all! That's how much she hates me.I'm sorry, Alice. From now on, I'll make sure you never see my face ever again. Jane exhaled a tired breath. Jane had failed to change the one thing she wanted. But it's not that bad… she thought, touching the text that conveyed Jane's promise to never let Alice see her face again.Maybe I didn't change what I wanted, but it is a better future.Out of curiosity, she glanced to the opposite page, expecting another disaster written down for her.Right… they're empty until… until… but as Jane thought that, something shattered the life out of her.Ding-ding-ding-ding!!Jane brough her head down in haste. A teacher? Dean? Madison? No. It was… God damn you, clock! Jane cursed in her mind.And from the front of the room, a curt, groan slumped ahead. "God damn you… clock!!" Madison shouted, half-asleep.I didn't expect to agree with Madison on something today…Jane sighed in relief as she lowered her defenses. She closed the diary half-way, and realized something off about it.The two pages open had the ink of an entry on them. But how? Did I flip a page when I got jump-scared? Jane checked the left page, reading February 6th, 1973 as the title. So if that was the entry she read not a minute ago, then that meant…Jane looked a the old clock and its swinging golden pendulum. 12 A.M.That's when new entries show up…The diary had always had, what Jane always felt, a sort-of demonic feeling to it. Something otherworldly; something inhumane. But seeing it happen in real time was something else completely.A shiver skuttled through Jane's spine.No! I beat it today, and I'll beat it tomorrow!Expecting some catastrophe to be revealed, Jane commenced the reading of the next entry of the foretelling diary. Dear diary, Today, was surprisingly good! Alice no longer gave me that cold look every time we had fun, and out-of-nowhere, Miss Mary talked to me about how things were going. It was so nice of her, even when she looked so tired.I hope every day from now on goes like this. Jane blinked and re-read the text a couple of times, unsure of what to take from this. No disaster? No Jane getting into some problem she had nothing to do with? I'm amazed… Alongside that, she also felt relief beyond the imagination. As if the clogs of her heart cleared, giving her a sense of energy she had never felt before.Jane closed the diary and shoved it where it belonged. She closed the curtains and, having her mind clear, she could hear what seemed to be a series of weak groans and No's being uttered in a hazy voice.Jane peaked over and found Alice's face scrunched and sweaty.Jane sat and something inside her told her what to do. She brought her hand and brushed Alice's head over and over again. Though the sensations felt bizarre and unfamiliar, but this seemed to be the right thing to do.Alice's face relaxed, and her breathing went back to normal."Schlaf gut, liebling," Jane's voice said.Jane covered her mouth in shock.What did I just say…? …It was a bright, snowy day outside.So… cold…Jane huddled herself as her teeth clanged. Sitting at the far right corner of the gray classroom has always been a favorable spot—alongside its twin opposite corner, it had the least neighboring desks besides being as far away from any teacher as possible. This time, though, it the desk furthest away from the room radiator, as well as being next to the window.Shucks…Jane was woken today by the most unordinary circumstance: being kicked off the bed. My side still hurts… she lightly patted the left of her stomach, brushing her palm against the soft, white wool of her turtleneck sweater. She didn't feel annoyed or anything—in fact, she felt bad that she had accidently woken up Alice when she tried get back in bed.But Jane and Alice weren't the only ones who woke up early and were sitting in the classroom. Dean was hunched over in his chair two desks away from Alice. His brown hair was ruffled and uncombed, and his collar wasn't flipped right.Woosh, a powerful gust of air swept across the room. Cold! Cold! Ahhh!! Jane kicked the floor in a attempt to release her numb her mind from the pain. But it was then, in a flash, a star appeared: an intricate construct of purity, sharp at all angles.Jane's pain faded, as her one eye followed the crystal. It swirled up to the checkered ceiling, then over the one-winged ceiling fan, all the way until it lightly settled on a mound of golden hair surrounded by wrapped bandages. It didn't take long for the sharp snow to melt away into nothing but water under the light of a ray peaking from dense clouds.Alice shook her head with a Brrr. She tried to raise her left hand up to her head, but it only moved a couple centimeters before she inhaled sharply and realized that was the wrong hand to use.Jane felt the arms of regret hold her closely. Her vision slumped.How bad does it hurt, Alice? Jane brought her left forearm and pushed it against the sharp edge of her table at a right angle. She felt bone under skin touching the wood corner. She put pressure, then more pressure, but it didn't feel painful enough. She loosened it, then slam! This time, it hit hard, and a wave of tingling pain elevated up to her brain instantly.Ouch! Ah…! she squeezed her arm tight and breathed quietly, making sure not to make her cries audible.I can't do it… she rested her forehead on her bible, her body tensing with each wave of the pain. I'm sorry, Alice. I've sinned against you.Yesterday's conversation flashed by, and Alice's smile seemed to shine in the dark of Jane's memories. I'll make it up to you. She unglued her hade from the table. I promise.There was, after all, another perspective to this.Maybe I'm too much of a wuss to cover my own butt, but if this… Jane locked her eye on Dean, a red film dropping before the lens of her eye, if this BULLY hadn't been such an awful boy, none of this would've happened!Dean was no lunged hunched over. Instead, he was studying Alice with a dangerous glint to his eyes. She hadn't noticed his stare yet, and was still fixing her hair. Dean looked around, skipping Jane from his vision, and preparing his body to stand up.Jane's body reacted quickly, rising up and pushing her chair back away from her with a screech. Dean noticed it and locked eyes with Jane. Instantly, his face broke down in a hideous glower, his skin distorting with the muscles of his skull. He fell back down to his chair and punched his table, saying something without making a noise. So' o' a be… Sun over a beach? Jane tried to trace it, but was unsuccessful.What were you thinking to do, Evergreen…?Alice suddenly flipped her head back to Jane. "Wha'cha doin' there in the cold? There's a sweaty pipe right here," she pointed at the radiator against the nearby wall. "Come over."Jane nodded obediently, picked up her book, and sat to the desk next to Alice."That's better." She smiled.Jane looked away, "Th-thanks…" She said quietly.The class door suddenly swung half-open, then was hit by something to open fully."Look alive… children," said Miss Mary as she was rubbing her nose. She looked twice as miserable and thrice as worn out since the last time Jane saw her after that… incident with Connor and his pictures. "Feeling tired today…" Miss Mary looked around, "Where is everyone?"Dean raised an arm. "It's still early for class," his voice had no hint of that ugly frown he had not a minute ago."Oh," Miss Mary looked down and fixed her jacket slipping down to her shoulder. Her eye found Jane, and she blinked a couple of times. "Dear… you're in the front row today?"Jane tried to say yes, but decided on a quick nod instead."That's nice," Miss Mary's expression relaxed. "Let's start anyways," she picked up the chalk and wrote Isaia 1:18 atop the blackboard in wiggly handwriting."Ma'am," Dean raised his hand again, "It's Isaiah with an H…"Miss Mary looked between Dean and title, whispering to herself, "Really?" Without checking, she added the H and said, "Open your pages to… I think somewhere between page 85 and 94…? Just search for the verse."She doesn't look good, Jane thought as she flipped through verses. The diary had said she wanted to checkup on me, but doesn't someone need to checkup on her instead?The class went on quite badly actually. Miss Mary had many errors in her explanations, and many times, she just dozed off looking at the blackboard, Dean made no attempt to approach Alice with that ugly expression of his, and Alice just looked around in boredom, making a funny face or a bizarre remark to Jane here and there.But like how the diary predicted, at the end of the class, Miss Mary had asked Jane to accompany her to her office.Walking in, Jane's first impression was that the office was… well… clean.Don't You Miss Sunday Services! a cup said, and unlike the last time, it didn't have mountains of documents and medicine on it, but Jane had noticed that the cabinet next to the entrance looked a little fat per se. On the carpet in front of it, was an empty box of with a pretty lady and the label Headache Free - NO RISKS on it."Yeah, dear… Sit down." Miss Mary gestured to the rickety chair in the center of the room as she walked behind her desk and sat down with her fingers intertwined in a professional pose. "So… What was I going to say? Right. How has school been?" Her voice was off. It had a low grainy tone to it, but it raised itself above comfort point."I… I d-don't know…" Jane fiddled with her fingers, cracking knuckles, "Okay, I think…" Jane felt like Miss Mary wasn't being honest, and so Jane felt no desire to be honest either. It's 'okay' if you don't count me getting Alice thrown down the stares…Miss Mary nodded enthusiastically, her ginger locks bobbing along. "That's… that's good! How was the food?""G-good, actually… Thanks… for that…""Your very welcome, dear.""And—" Jane wanted to stand up and say this loudly, but she resorted to more calm measures, "I, uh, about… C-Connor… Thanks for b-beating him up for me…"Miss Mary's eyes lit up. "Of course, dear! If you want, I can beat'em up daily for you," she looked far too interested in what seemed like a joke… or so thought Jane."N-no, thanks… One time is fine…"She chuckled, but it just sounded like a hollow exhale. "I also made sure… that he can't visit you out of nowhere… So, to… uh… put it simply, he can only come once a week, and that is with my permission."That felt like ice on a fire. Recently, with the diary and Jane's broken memories and Alice and her broken bones and Dean and his malicious ploys, Jane's life felt like an absurd knot. It was relieving to know that one end of this multi-roped knot was being loosened. Jane felt irritated, because she knew she was the worst person in the world to show appreciation, and right now, she felt nothing but appreciation.She shook her head up and down fast, repeating the motion over and over again with whispers of Thank you in-between.Miss Mary chuckled, her expression falling for a second. "Not a problem in the world, dear." She leaned over, "Is there anything else I can do for you? Anything…?" There was a hint of desperation in her voice.Jane examined her for a second, thinking. There was some stuff, but, something drove her to not care for them. Instead, she jumped off the chair, and walked up until half of her face, half-obscured by her black hair, was showing atop the desktop."Yes, dear?""Are you okay?" Jane asked."Right as rain.""R-really?""Of course, dear. You don't need to worry.""But—""Jane, I'm fine!" Miss Mary slammed the table.Jane faltered back and fell down."No—" Miss Mary extended a hand, horror in her eyes.Suddenly, the cabinet at the front of the room exploded. Papers whirled in the room: from unpaid bills to warrants. A pile of headache medicine and a bunch of other trash must've been jostled pretty hard into the cabinet and it simply couldn't hold it in any longer.Miss Mary smashed her head against the table and shouted, "God damn it!" she dug her fingers into her hair."M-Miss…?" Jane drew back."I'm" Miss Mary breathed deeply, "I'm fine. I just—" she massaged her temples, "I'm just didn't drink my morning coffee. That's it…" She groaned and covered her face. "Who am I kidding?" her voice cracked. "I'm a mess!""B-b-but," Jane stood up, her legs wobbly, "we have three m-months, right?""That's the problem!" Miss Mary threw her hands in the air. "We're short on staff, bills keep coming, there are no donors in sight, Father Oswald still refuses to change his mind about the church donations, and I'm here," she hit her chest and a loud thud echoed, "making a little girl get involved in a cult investigation so we can have food on the table!""We m-might have three months…" Jane's voice shook, but Jane held it for as long as she could, "but if you f-fell, we would have z-zero months…"Miss Mary's jaw dropped in one Ha noise, then it turned into two, then three, then a loud, energetic laugh. "Don't tell anyone this. But if I would choose, I would have picked anyone—man woman or child—to put them in your position instead of you having to do this."Jane walked around the desk and Miss Mary opened her arms for her. Jane walked in slowly until Miss Mary brought her in for a spine-breaking embrace. It felt nice and soothing, and in a sense, healing."You're lovely," said Miss Mary as she patted Jane's hair. "So," she rocked Jane left and right, "now that the pretense fell, what do you really want, Jane? I'll do anything.""B-but—""Yeah, yeah, I'll also rest, buuuut," she poked her nose, "this ain't about your old lady here. It's about the you, young lady."Jane thought as to how to word this without cutting her own finger. "Recently… I've c-committed a… sin," she looked up in Miss Mary's glistening eyes, "What am I meant to do, miss? I feel so bad…""What kind of sin?"Jane groaned, not wanting to lie, but also not wanting to speak about it."You think you've sinned, and I could try to guess what you did, but I could do better. Let me ask you this," Miss Mary turned Jane's body and set her on her lap, "what did you do after you realized you sinned?""…I'm trying to make it up?""Exactly," Moss Mary smiled wide, and all the weariness disappeared from her face. "We can't erase our sins from existence, but you we can work towards making things right by doing whatever we can. You needn't ask me anything. You were already doing the right thing because you're a good young lady, arench'a!" She squeezed Jane's cheek and played with it."Ah…!" Jane protested, pushing the rough hand away."I'm sorry, I didn't mean to…" said Miss Mary with cheekiness to her voice.I am trying to make it up, but I don't how! If I just tell on Dean, I feel like it wouldn't do anything. Any other bully could replace Dean, and Alice would still be hurt. She has to do it, but it has to work. Jane shook her head. No, Miss Mary is right. I'm doing the right thing by just helping her with whatever I can."One more thing…" Jane dropped off of Miss Mary's lap and tried to remember it—remember how it sounded. "What d-does this mean: Sch-schlaf g-gut, liebling…?"Miss Mary crossed her arms. "I'm not too sure. This is definitely German, but I don't know language well enough to tell you. I'm sorry, dear.""N-no, it's okay…""I will say, though. When you meet Mr. Angelo next time, ask him if he knows."Jane tilted her head. "Is M-Mr. Angelo German?""No, dear, but that man knows too many languages to count. In fact, I would say…He accounts for half of the staff force here." … The diary continued its more calm predictions, and Jane was more than happy to simply go along with them. No mention of danger—actual danger, that is—and no mention of Connor. Miss Mary said he's only allowed to come once a week, but she didn't exactly say when.It was Saturday 11:59 P.M. when Jane opened the diary to see… Hey diary, At the church today, I met— "Whaz'that?" Alice peaked from behind Jane.Jane squealed a high-pitched sound and slammed the diary into her chest so hard, she began coughing."N-n-nothing…!" she managed in-between choking noises.Alice's eyes clouded as she hummed a deep noise."It's really… n-nothing…" Jane felt the biting bitter taste of lying on the tip of her tongue."'Kay," said Alice before she lied back down and rolled his face as far away as she could.Jane has realized lately that the diary was kind of an addiction. It was like the safety of her day, its meaning and purpose, was fully tied to the words of it, and it always felt relieving to know those words were on Jane's side, and not against her.Maybe… maybe no diary for today… Jane slipped the notebook in-between her mattress and the bedframe. Yeah…! Who cares about who I meet in the church today? Ding-ding-ding! the clock hit the 12 mark, and kids groaned as their sleep got interrupted. Not reading it once a while should be fine. I was fine on Thursday,I should be fine now… …The air felt heavy with the weight of a song played by dozens of children—a celestial choir resonating through the church beeswax wooden interior.Are you washed in the blood of the Lamb~♪ Jane moved her lips with the lyrics, not contributing a noise to this creepy song. She and all her fellow foundlings and orphans played their part at the benches to the right of the hall. Children accompanied by their guardians, on the other hand, had the left side to them."Booooring!" Alice sank in her seat and dropped her head to the right, where she had a perfect view to the clouds beyond one of the lancet windows.Something felt wrong looking at her, and it wasn't her head bandages or the cast covering her left arm and right leg."Alice… where d-did you leave your c-crutch…?""Next to the bench," she said with a drawl.Jane scanned the area below the armrest where Alice's head perched atop, and there was it, a pale oak stick. Phew, Jane swept her sweat away.Looking back at the rows in front of her—and continuing her pretend game of singing—she had noticed something strange. Everyone was more or less looking at Father John behind the podium as they sang, all but for one person: Dean. He had a longing stare at the left side of the church, and his brows were droopy. It was hard to decipher the voices mixed in the choir, but if Jane focused, she could take out Desmos's out-of-tone voice, Lucy's angelic voice, but not Dean's. Is he pretending like me?That thought didn't last long, before the choir ended, and the clapping of the pastor echoed excitedly."Marvelous! Let's give a round of applause to our little angels!" he announced with a satisfied smile, and every other adults began clapping, engulfing the hall in celebratory noises. "Now, children," Father John said and white noise of clapping quieted down, "I'll guess that a lot of you are confused right now. You sang so beautifully about the blood of the lamb, but really, what is that?" He walked away from the podium and sat at the edge of the stage, dangling his feet down and looking around. "It sounds scary for sure, no?" he gestured to one kid.As a result, they pushed their head into their mother's dress. Dean made a quiet grunting noise."What it really tells is the biggest tragedy in the world," he clamped both hands and dropped his head down, his voice softening as he talked more to himself than to the audience. "See, we all carry sins with us—those times we falter and turn away from God; those times when we let our inner storms rain down upon the ones beside us."Jane felt thorns scrape her heart. She peeked to Alice, and she seemed as uninterested as before."It leaves a stain on our soul," Father John said with his voice growing louder, "and because Jesus loves you so much, he spilled his blood to cleanse all your sins—so it may become as white as snow."So what I did to Alice was fine…? It's a sin that has been cleansed…? It made very little sense to Jane, but her lack of understanding didn't stop the pastor to continue his lesson."Ahhhh, this torment's finally over!" stretched and groaned Alice after Father John announced the end of the class. She reached down next to her shoe, her hand found no crutch. Her expression knotted, and she began looking around her."I'll s-search too," Jane said, but her voice was more or less drowned by all the kids walking by towards the exit."Where the heck is it?"Jane fiddled with her fingers. "It's p-probably… him…"Alice pursed her lips in anger as her brows broke down. She tried pushing herself up, but the pain of it brought her down. Her visible anger faded, and there was nothing left but sad frustration.There was one real culprit for this."You have to t-tell the teachers…" Jane whispered."They won't listen—they never do!" Alice shouted as she punched the backrest of the front bench.Jane never had Alice talk to her this way. It was like a scary tsunami threatening to sink her boat. But if there is one thing Jane learned from Alice these past few days, was that things can work out sometimes, regardless of how hopeless or scary the situation looked.Jane shimmied next to Alice and bumped their shoulders. There was no more tsunami, no more storms, only an island. And on that island, there was one thing beyond sin and guilt, passed intrigue and curiosity, atop likeness and appeal.Inspiration."Lean on me. Let's go find him."Alice looked up at her with a disordered look—one that read, Was that you who just said that? But after the short phase, Alice stood up with Jane's help.The two exit and find a a wide, endless green field with a road and a small, battered truck. All the kids Jane knew from their class around it. Miss Mary was trying to catch Louis who seemed to have stole her car keys."Bring it back, you rascal!""Not until you convince Father John to give us cookies!"The kids around chanted Cookies! Cookies! Cookies!Jane's eye locked with Miss Mary, and she stopped in her tracks. There was a moment of bewilderment in her eyes."Where would he even go?" Alice said as she looked around. "There's literally nowhere to go."Jane picked up her pace and took a sharp turn.The two limbed around the church building, and found Dean exactly where Jane had expected him to be: behind the building."Hmm…" he was yanking Alice's crutch high in the air as it spun, then picking it back up as he walked circles.Jane stepped forth and a twig broke below her shoe."Jesus… Finally!" Dean made a dramatic gesture and swung the crutch around. "Took you this long… Wait—" His eye first landed on Alice, but once it moved to Jane, his face turned askew. "Again? You?!" he shouted."Yeah? Anything wrong with her?" Alice wagged her head in his direction. "You have an issue with'er, you have an issue with my fist down your throat, Evergreen."Jane felt that she would have blushed if she wasn't before an angry Dean with a weapon."You—I swear! Every time! Can you just stop!" he stomped forward until it was close enough for his crutch to hit any of the two girls. "Like, do I need to stop myself!?" he raised the crutch, and Jane stepped ahead of Alice and raised her shaky hands up in defence."What in the lord's name is going on here?" Miss Mary's chainsaw voice teared through. "Dean Evergreen!" she ran in and took his stick, "Explain yourself!"The cookie supporters must have come with Miss Mary, as murmurs began spreading from behind."I… I…" Dean looked around, his face red as beet, and at the edges of his eyes were tears. "She," he pointed a finger at Alice, "she tried to hit me! Multiple times even!"Miss Mary cocked her head in Alice's direction in a snap. "Is that true, Danger?" she said with an undertone of stone in her voice.Alice's eyes opened wide, her discs shuddering below Miss Mary's shadow.Jane held her hand and raised her up in a bump. Alice didn't look Jane's way, but Jane knew she got it."He's lying miss," Alice said flatly. "He's always lying.""Miss Director, you're not really gonna believe this trouble-maker, will you? You can't!"Miss Mary decided to look neither's Alice's nor Dean's direction this time. Instead, she focused her gaze on Jane, and so did Jane. Neither spoke nor gestured to the other, but there was some understanding between them.I know you won't choose wrong, thought Jane."That's it," Miss Mary planted one hand at her hip, and other pointed beyond, "Dean Evergreen, go wait in the van!""But—" he tried to protest, but Alice's crutch was swiftly taken away from him."Get outt'ere!" Miss Mary spanked him on his legs and butt with the crutch, causing the kids around to boom in laughter, and causing Dean to run off to the van crying.Miss Mary extended the crutch to Alice and said in a low voice, "This is yours. Try to keep it safe next time, will ya?"Taking it, Alice nodded enthusiastically. "Yeah! Thanksy-wanksy, Miss Director!""Now you too, everyone! Outta'ere!" Miss Mary shooed the other kids back to the van area.The two girls were quiet for the next couple of minutes, as both seemed unsure as to what to say. But suddenly, Jane got a punch to the shoulder."Ow…!" she rubbed the pained area, and it turned out Alice was the one who hit her."Sorry," she chucked, "I dunno how to do this, but I guess I could just say…" she blushed slightly as she turned away, "thank you, Jane." Her eyes were bright in summer cyan and her smile shined.Jane felt heavy in the chest. She couldn't take it longer. "I'm… sorry…" She looked down the grassy grounds. "I'm sorry…"Alice frowned. "Wha'cha sorrying for?"Jane played with her index, spinning it and pulling it. "If it w-weren't for me, you wouldn't be wearing all those b-bandages to begin with. You would b-be able to walk on your own."Alice flicked her nose hard and Jane's head fell back with an Ow! "Look, there, dummy. Didn't I say this already? Yes, I did. I don't want your apology. Because you don't need to apologize. Like," she Alice made an exasperated huff, "I was the one who put myself there!" She crossed her arms. "You know, for being this smart, you're kinda of a dummy sometimes."Jane's jaw fell. She covered her face as embarrassment and shame washed over her. "You're right!" she cried aloud, "I am a d-dummy!""Woah, there… I didn't actually mean it…""But… you're right! The diary had s-said this from the b-beginning!""The what?"It was there from the start. She didn't want my apology, the diary had said, and Jane completely missed that that could have had a more positive meaning. So me changing the future for the better was all a lie? A stupid lie? But it hit her: I'm sorry, Alice. From now on, I'll make sure you never see my face ever again, the diary said, and that was still wrong.The future still changed.Rubbing tears off her eyes, Jane thought, I guess I should stop being so pessimistic…"You 'kay?" Alice tried patting Jane on the head."I'm fine… b-but… why didn't you tell her about him k-kicking you down the stairs…?"Alice shrugged. "I think he actually didn't mean it."The end of Jane's lips rose uncontrollably. She was truly inspired."Anyhoo… kinda need to pee… badly…""Uh," Jane thought for a moment as to what to say, "good luck?"Alice held a laugh as she walked away. "You're funny."Feeling that she needed to sit, Jane walked back to the church again. She felt as light as a feather as she took a seat, her breathing cold, and her mind calm. It all, for once, was good.It was then that a thought appeared in her mind.At the church today, I met—At that moment, when Jane felt the presence of an towering shadow sitting next to her—where her eye saw no light. Her heart froze, and it was almost as if death itself had embraced her from the back, its scythe swinging near her neck."So, child," the shadow began speaking with a voice so threateningly calm, "what knowledge has Father John bestowed upon you today?"Jane's breathing was broken. She inhaled and exhaled, but her brain kept clogging up. Something about this was wrong—very wrong."I hear of him going with sin today. I am intrigued," every move from the shadow was only audible through rustles of clothes, and each move stabbed Jane in the heart. "Jesus has died for us. He and his sacrifice purified our sins. What a joke." Jane winced as he spat the last words. "Say, child, what is your perspective on this?"Jane began crying, but she forced herself not to make a single noise out of it. Out of sheer force, she had said what she thought first."D-doing whatever… you c-can to m-m-make things… right…?"There was a quick exhale from the shadow. It was surely a chuckle or a snort of sorts, but its tone felt unnatural."That has Mary Patterson written all over it. Say, child, it is your turn to ask me what my perspective is. It's only fair."Like a marionette, her lips opened. "Wh-what is y-your p-p-perspective…?""Glad you asked," he put a hand around Jane, and she could only wish to be in her gave by that point, "I say to erase it." He came closer and whispered. "Who would notice a small grain of sand taken from an hourglass? It's a crime with no thief."Jane shut her eyes close, her mind close, and expect that scythe to slice her neck."Father Oswald! What an honor to see you here!" said the familiar happy Father John.Feeling like she's no longer alone with this shadow, Jane gathered the courage to look up and see. And see, she did. It was no one but a simple-looking bold man. He wore a black rope and had a silver cross dangling from his neck. His brows—or lack there of—were raised in serendipity. He closed his deep dark eyes and laughed."Was just messin' around," he ruffled Jane's hair and brought up a wrapped plank. "A friend brought me this, and for a hot moment, I thought I could keep it. But I couldn't help but feel guilty to steal from the artist." He winked at Jane with a mischievous.He gave the plank to Jane, and she teared it apart after wiping her tears, curious to see that… it was just her painting of herself from a couple days ago. Her ugly drawing of a vase with two eyes, one of which had Xs and scratches covering it."You l-liked this…?" Jane asked."It's beautiful," the man said before standing up.Jane's internal warning systems all began returning to normal, but she couldn't help but to think why they all activated to begin with. It's just like the diary and Alice! I have to stop being so pessimistic!The man bowed lightly to the pastor of the church and said, "Father John."Father John bowed in return, "Father Oswald."I feel like I know this name… Deep within the vines of her mind, something pulsated with that name, but it was obvious.Father Oswald still refuses to change his mind about the church donations!He was the man, with his charming smile and his playful attitude.He was the one who wanted the orphanage down.
