item.title: Jane Patterson and the Foretelling Diary (First Draft)
item.description: This is a work of fiction. All characters, settings, and events are merely a figment of my own imagination. Any resemblance to people, places, or real life events is purely coincidental. The work is unpublished and incomplete — any unauthorized redistribution is prohibited, (kindly.) Copyrighted RainMaster69 The following story contains disturbing topics revolving around CHILDREN, including depictions of the following: PHYSICAL ABUSE, DRUG USAGE, ABANDONMENT, AND MORE. It was happening again.Jane Patterson opened her eyes.And what she saw was nothing but nothingness itself. Thick darkness veiled the surroundings from all directions, and only one entity stood center stage: a gleaming, red bathtub. She felt her chest shiver—the slightly painful type of shiver."H-hello…? Is… is anyone here?" she inquired, turning her head away from the tub and checking for any possible reaction. "I'm scared…" Her statement was only met by its own echo. Though the scenery wasn't unfamiliar, It still gave Jane the heebie-jeebies. It wasn't her fault the only dream she had was this abomination.Standing in the void amidst deafening silence was something, but being in the same space as that bathtub, was something else entirely. It stank with ominosity, as if knives and hammers swung all round it, or as if touching it would poison her to death, or simply hurt her. The fear was as much instinctive as it was reactional, yet, it wasn't logical, as she had no real reason to fear the tub. With no desire to walk up to it, Jane decided to walk away from it. She moved a good five-meters and turned back. The bathtub was as close as it was before she had moved. Of course, she thought. Nothing new.But suddenly, an idea struck her. Jane was a tiny kid, not that she liked that fact, and due to her height, she was never able to see what was in the bathtub from the distance it was in before. Coming closer to it was an idea out of the picture; out of the room; and out the house, but peeking at what was inside of it intrigued her. She took a long breath and raised her body atop her tippy-toes. Right at the distant end of the bathtub, she saw what looked to be deep, blue water, and the moment that water reflected in Jane's eyes, something squeezed her heart like a stress toy. Suddenly, there was no floor, and Jane was falling at high speed.It was only then, when she truly opened her eye. … Jane jolted awake, her heart racing. The left side of her chin and the shoulder below it were completely damp in drool, likewise the open book in her lap. One of the lines was drenched, but barely readable: Big Bee wants justice. Big Bee wants honey.She looked around in a daze, seeing towers of bookshelves and orange stars made of glass. Did I sleep the entire night? A glimpse at the clock above the broad double-doors showed that the small, chunky hand pointed at IV and the tall, thin one between XI and XII. She pondered for a second as her brain ran calculations. Six… no, no… When there is an I to the left, you take one away… so four in the morning. There was plenty of time before the bell rang and the day began."Morning there, missy," an old man said, causing Jane to jump and fall on her side. The man croaked a chuckle and bent over his round desk, smiling to her. "You snored like a hummingbird," he said, his gentle eyes unassuming above his round spectacles."G-good morning… to… too, Mr. Angelo," she said, her mind attempting to imagine what a hummingbird was before she could imagine it snoring. Mr. Angelo drew back and disappeared from Jane's vision. It was best if she went back to her reading, but she wasn't that delighted to go through the book for the umpteenth time. She thought for a moment, and realized a possible solution, though it required her to use her voice again… She shivered, but stood up nevertheless, wiping away the drool off her face. She left her book at the floor, making a mental note to return to it later."Um, Mr. Angelo…" she mumbled, only the top half of her pale, ghostly face, half-obscured by black hair, visible above the desktop, "Is… is there… is there…" She was taken back by the fact that Mr. Angelo was reading his book upside down. "Wh-why… read it that way?"He looked at the book, back at Jane, then smiled, "Why not?"Mr. Angelo was always strange, Jane reminded herself. Back on topic, "I was… gonna ask. Is there anything you recommend?""Of course," he said with enthusiastic body language, "everything!""How about… um… something more specific?" Jane was not about read everything, unless that was a book on its own. She looked down for a moment, her pink slippers looked back at her with googly eyes. "Something… nice?" she said, looking up cautiously to check Mr. Angelo's expression. His optics drilled into her with a thoughtful look. She looked away again. "Y-you know… Like all the other ones I read."He sighed, "Unfortunately, you've read all those books." Jane heard noises of thumps and papers moving. "But how about this." She looked up and found Mr. Angelo holding up a book with the title The Adventures of Sherlock Holmes written above, and By A. Conan Doyle written below it. She knew this one. "It has… murder in it," she said."It's a fine book. Good puzzles and all.""I do not… like it…""It's a little difficult, sure, but—""I don't want to.""You haven't given it a try. If only you—""No!" she said in Mr. Angelo's face with loud enough volume to leave a trail of reverberation in the room. Upon realizing her ill-manners, Jane covered her mouth and looked down in shame. "I'm sorry," she whimpered."You'll eventually run out, you know," Mr. Angelo said with a warm, but firm, voice. "You'll eventually be left with nothing but the books you hate, and what will you do then?"Jane stayed silent at that. Part of her regretted asking Mr. Angelo in the first place.Mr. Angelo took a deep inhale, then a long exhale. From the corner of her watery eye, Jane saw his hand rise and point in a direction behind her. "You'll find a new batch of books below Saint Mathew's window. Maybe something there will catch your attention."Jane lifted her head slowly. Mr. Angelo returned to his usual smile, but she couldn't help but feel that there was a hint of trouble in his eyes. It was probably her that troubled him. At the very least, she would need to keep her manners in place."Thank you," she said with a nod, and he nodded too, before returning to his upside down study. … Jane found herself in a narrow passage between the far wall of the library and a soaring bookshelf opposite to it. High above, four stained windows washed the library with color—mainly a soft hue of red, which brought a feeling of tension and religious significance.Like how Mr. Angelo said, there was a pile of unorganized books below one of the windows, most likely Matthew's. She approached the possible pile of time-devouring entertainment and began her search on the floor. From books of languages Jane didn't understand, to books of topics she had no interest in. The pile was starting to dwindle when Jane found something fascinating: an untitled, leather-bound notebook. Who would donate their own notebook? Jane thought as she opened the cover to check its content. Jane Patterson… Like, Me Patterson? she thought, trying to comprehend what she was seeing. Such a bizarre coincidence to find a diary with the exact same name as Jane. The time recorded was also this year. Now much more intrigued, Jane flipped a page and commenced her reading. Dear diary, Today, a new year rolls in, and it also happens to be the one year anniversary of my stay at the Pittyfall House of Children as a foundling. My memory hasn't improved one bit. I still don't remember nine years of my life. I still don't remember who's my mom or my dad. I still don't remember anything. Jane's jaw was on the floor. I don't understand, her brain called out as all the logic units went out of commission. This month-old entry recorded what seemed to be an exact parallel of what Jane had felt that exact day. But that was absurd. There had to be an explanation for this. Jane flipped to another page and continued reading, her eyes mere centimeters away from the paper. Good morning diary, Alice Danger found some firecrackers, and from the sounds of the screams, it looks like she's terrorizing the other kids with it. Thankfully, she doesn't come to the library. I found a nice book called We Bumble Bees. It's so fun. I love Big Bee! No, no, no! her head was spinning, and her face was glued to the pages of the diary, so much so that it looked like the notebook was eating her. It felt like she was chasing her own tail, trying to find something besides the obvious. Her heart froze in time. It was difficult to breath, and though the room was warm and cozy, Jane was shivering. From a sitting pose, she fell back down and the hair that covered the right side of her face fell away, revealing a silver eye with an old gash going through it. It was a stark contrast to the eye next to it, which was dark. Her lips were cautious as they shaped each syllable of the words from today's entry. Good evening diary, Today, I got in trouble and ended up in the director's office. It felt like hours in there, and I ended up losing my favorite book today, We Bumble Bees. I'm so sad… The diary slipped out of Jane's hands and fell on her face. She made no attempt to pick it up, or any attempt to move for that matter. She simply laid down in silence, foolishly attempting to process what she had just read. Hours passed while she was in her diseased pose, not asleep, but fully awake.Were the doctors right when they said I've lost my mind? Or did this diary just predict the future? She thought over the entry: So I'll be in trouble, be scolded and punished for hours, and then my favorite book will be taken? This is the worst! But that was only if the diary is not some prank, which Jane believed it to be, as there was no other explanation.A bell rang in the distance, and though it was typically the most annoying thing to hear in the world, when its so far that it no longer scrapped your ears, it was surprisingly soothing. Jane wanted to sleep so badly, her conscious mushy and soft, slipping away into dream land. But Jane knew what she had in dream land. It was better to not doze off. As she lifted her back, the diary fell away. She pondered momentarily about what she would do with it, but she realized she didn't want to do anything with it. She wanted it to leave her mind, as it was already cluttered. She took the notebook and shoved it in the narrow space between the shelf and the floor. Out of sight, out of mind. When she walked back, she found that Mr. Angelo was not behind the round desk. … Jane was happy that her seat was located at the far corner of the classroom. If that diary had a sliver of accuracy, it would be favorable if Jane was hidden, especially when considering how well her gray attire camouflaged her amidst the colorless light surging through the windows from gloomy clouds.The yapping and barking of children were silenced instantly at the loud yank of the classroom door. A short, plump woman with ginger hair came in quickly, speaking in a professional let's-get-over-with-it tone."Morning children.""Good morning, Miss Mary Patterson," everyone said in unharmonized unison. It was always strange hearing that surname. A mother? No, just a staff member who gave their surname to a child who didn't remember theirs.With speed and elegance, she wrote the title Psalm 34:4 on the chalkboard and spoke to the children as if she had an eye on the back of her head. "Desmos, stop eating the paper. You will choke. Louis, stop laughing at Desmos and tell your sister to focus on the subject. Art class can wait. And Alice," she turned around and looked down at the blond-haired girl glaring at the kid next to her, "it's rude to stare. You're gonna make Dean uncomfortable," Alice made a huffing noise before she looked away dramatically.Looks normal… Jane assured herself. If something bad were to happen, it wasn't now for sure. As the class went on, Jane decided to immerse herself with the view outside. Dead trees and mud. That was all what the rusted bars had enclosed, that and the grimy Jesus statue in the middle. But behind those bars, Jane saw someone. A tall figure next to a sleek, black car. It was then when the classroom door opened once more. Jane shifted her attention to it and found Mr. Angelo."Miss Director," he said with unease and began whispering to her."Christ…" She clicked her tongue and went back to writing on the board, "Tell him the only thing waiting for him here is a beating."Mr. Angelo nodded and exited the room. Not a blink of an eye later, Jane found him walking up to the tall man behind the bars. That was fast… she thought and blamed her consciousness for dozing off. A small exchange later, and the tall man cupped his hands over his mouth and yelled."Hey, honey. Do not make me get a warrant." All kids crooked their heads towards the monotone, yet sarcastic, voice.Miss Mary opened one of the windows with a surprisingly strong motion. "I'll make you, jackass." She closed it and pulled the curtains down. Everyone kept staring at her. "Back to class—and, you didn't hear me cuss." That was met with moans and groans of disappointment.Well, that was not normal, Jane thought, but it wasn't her causing trouble, or being scolded for hours, or having her favorite book taken. Not normal, but good so far…And it was good all the way through, except for the end: class had concluded and kids were scattering when Miss Mary came over to Jane's table. No trouble… No trouble… she repeated in her head. "Mind helping me organize some papers later, dear? I just have a lot on my plate lately," she said.Jane barely heard her over the thumping of her heart. She nodded. As long as trouble was off-frame. She nodded obediently, and received Miss Mary's rough hand as it ruffled her hair. … Jane spent her free time like a pray in the wild, keeping her best to stay safe. Would the person she had just bumped into attack her and make a fuss out of it? No, but they did say she looked like an ugly ghost—it was an upper classmate. Would the floor that had just creaked under her feet break and cause her to go to detention? No, but it did scare the living daylight out of her. Was Mr. Carl about to grab Jane and beat her like he always did with the other naughty children? No, but he did jabber about Jane's tousled hair and her untidy clothes.This diary and its entry were getting to Jane too much. It was probably just a prank. An unfunny and cruel one. She was not about to let a stack of papers get the best of her. Her anger forged her motivation, and she stomped her way through the halls. Her goal: somewhere quiet, aka the backyard.As she reached last corner, Dean passed her, flashing a bright smile. It was only too late when she had realized that he actually said Hello to her. "Oh—um, h-hi, there…" she said, but he was way too far to hear her. Dean was one of the few kids Jane considered to be a good apple, and here she was ignoring him. Embarrassment swirled in her head as it slumped down. She only deserved to look at the floor from now on.After a turn, she was seeing surging light from the backdoor making the wood below her brighter each step. It was then when something rolled onto Jane's shoes: a green crayon. She picked it up and read the cutoff text Starlight Color Works (SPECIAL EDIT- in her mind. Nothing out of the ordinary, she thought and a rustle scuttled before her. She looked up, and what she saw there made her heart squelch. It was Alice. Her face was covered in green, and she was out of breath."N-no trouble, please…" Jane trembled.Alice's eyes seemed unfocused, but she saw them glance to the right for a split-second. That was where Jane could not see. She turned her head and faced the worst possible thing to see.Mary Patterson's a BITCH! was written on the adjacent wall with a radiant green color. The same crayon that Jane was holding… Immediately, she snapped her head back at Alice, but she had already ran far in the backyard. In a moment of complete panic, Jane wound up her hand and shoulder, ready to throw the crayon into the next continent if necessary. But suddenly, a rough hand squeezed hers, taking the crayon from it. Though Jane knew who that hand belonged to, she was still aghast when the face of Mary Patterson drew in front of her."What a troublemaker," Miss Mary mumbled, her eyes at the crayon.Jane wasn't even worth to be looked down upon. "N-no… It… I…" she shrilled, attempting to explain herself and failing miserably.Miss Mary looked at Jane suddenly and her expression changed in a way Jane didn't understand. "Wait in my office," she said before leaving.Jane stood still for a while, unsure whether to cry or fall down and pretend to die. She didn't want to be scolded by Miss Mary. She respected her, but now that she knew that diary was correct—that it predicted the truth, however painful that truth was, Jane didn't see how she could escape the scolding. … The familiar room felt suffocating.Jane sat on a rickety wooden chair before a desk with a huge pile of papers, a cup of coffee with Don't You Miss Sunday Services! written on it, and a bunch of pill packs with the title Headache Free - NO RISKS and a picture of a pretty lady with a set of blinding teeth set beside it. She felt her body with five times its typical weight, as if gravity was her enemy. Her mind was a collection of staircases and pathways that all lead to the image of how Jane would be scolded—insulted—humiliated. It felt like hours in there, the diary had said, and Jane was living those hours at the moment. Her heart was so jammed in her throat, she felt she would throw up at any point. It all felt sickening.In a minute or two, Jane would have to face Miss Mary's fury for what she had not done, and explaining herself, with her clumsy tongue and such damning evidence against her, felt useless. She was trapped, and she desired to escape so badly. Run out the room and hide somewhere, she thought to herself. Anywhere.The sound of a footstep suddenly slipped from below the door behind her, which did nothing but made her anxiety reach boiling point. Her main escape route was now blocked.As if her body moved on its own, Jane jumped off the chair and zipped to the next best thing: the office private bathroom. She would hide there until Miss Mary left, then sneakily leave after. It was no perfect plan, but it was a plan. Jane slammed her small body against the door as she missed to catch the handle multiple times. At last, she grasped it, swung the door, shoved herself in, and closed it behind her, making sure to click the lock. She glued her left ear against the door and did her best to keep her breathing down.A distant door swung open with a creak. Steps thudded vibrations across the floor. Then, a pause."She didn't come, huh…" Jane heard Miss Mary's muffle.Rat-tat, a postmen-like knock punched the air."In," Miss Mary said.Another creak later, Jane heard that familiar monotone voice once more."Got my warrant," the motionless voice said."Good," she said out of her teeth, "what's the occasion?"Jane turned around, discouraged by eavesdropping on Miss Mary when she was this heated. She studied the bathroom she was in as a distraction. A cracked mirror cabinet, an orange, curtained window emanating the fuzzy light of the early afternoon, and one, gleaming, red bathtub.A shiver jolted up Jane's spine and activated something in her head. Something that dragged her out of her body and somewhere far away, sometime far off. … Jane saw a bathroom—a cramped, old one. But not the same one she had just been in. A different one. It reeked of a medicinal smell, sharp and bitter.A dream? she thought, but it was clear she had no control over the body she possessed. This was a memory. A memory that was surging through a crack on the dam of her head.Besides seeing and smelling, she also felt things—intangible things. She felt oppressed and trapped. She felt exhausted and sickened. She felt something rattle at her wrist. It was a chain. She was attached to the faucet of the red bathtub that was full of blue water. She also sensed her clothes fully drenched in that same water. From the mess on the tiled floor, it looked like she had dragged herself out of the tub by sheer force.But atop all those feelings, there was one that washed everything. It was a searing, pulsating pain throbbing in her head. Unbelievably bad, to the point that moving her eyes caused it to intensify greatly.What a miserable place. What a miserable life.She suddenly heard that someone was approaching and every cell of her body screamed in terror.The door behind her screeched slowly, and he walked in. … Jane opened her eye, both of her hands holding her head. It was not hurting—it never did. She breathed deeply, her body shivering. She got out before she understood who he was, but she was very glad. She didn't want to see what was there, and now, she didn't want to stay here. She had to leave.She took one glance at the red shell of the tub before unlocking the door and exiting, her eyes downcast and mouth open. Not a dream, but a memory, she thought to herself."Jane?" Miss Mary said in disbelief, a letter in her hand.Right. Jane was trying to hide. She looked up at her, then to the tall man besides hers, with his purple eyebags and dead fish expression, before she broke down and sobbed. There was much inside of her, from her fear of being scolded, to that awful memory she had just seen. It was like she was trying to speak those feelings, but the words came out as cries and whimpers instead of eligible syllables.Miss Mary rushed in to embrace her. "Dear, what happened?" She sounded hoarse. "Why are you crying?"Jane didn't answer. She didn't know how. So she cried for a while until the tears dried up and she was left with only sniffles. One positive thing that came out of this was that these cries seemed to have calmed Miss Mary down, because it didn't look like she was mad at Jane anymore."Oh, taking care of your little dumplings must be hard…" the tall man said, "Now that the orphanage is closing, I believe the difficulty would be bumped into impossible.""C-closing?" Jane said through sniffles, "What does he mean?" she looked at Miss Mary with reddened eyes."It's…" she looked away, "It's…""Church no longer wants to support the orphans with donations," the man interjected, "I'm sure they have a real good reason for that.""And they do!" Miss Mary said confidently, "I'm sure they do…" her voice trailed off."Of course there is. It's called Godeyes. The cult responsible for the many recent goofy activities within the church.""You do not know for sure," she said and turned with a pointed finger."Of course I don't know for sure, dummy. If I did, I would've put them all in jail already. It's just a matter of time."Jane was beginning to lose the topic, but one thing concerned her above all else. "I-is the orphanage really closing?"Miss Mary turned to her, "Don't worry, Jane, I'll… I'll find—""Pardon me," the man interrupted and stepped forth between the two, "Jane? Like, the kid we found in the streets a year ago?" He looked at Jane curiously. "Right, Jane Patterson…" He then shifted into a more deep and thoughtful look."Mind shoving aside?" Miss Mary told him.He moved with no comments, keeping that same look."Look, I'll find a new donor as fast I can," Miss Mary said, "You do not worry—""Of course," the man interrupted once again, "how could I have missed this…""What is it now?" Miss Mary said, her patience running thin and her fist clenching tighter than ever."Honey, I believe we can strike quite a beneficial deal," he said and came over to Jane, "A deal that will surely interest you." Though he was talking while looking at Jane, he seemed more focused on something beyond her.Jane eyed Miss Mary with confusion and dread as she only imagined what his deal would be."What does your deal entail?" Miss Mary inquired, her eyes hostile.The man kept his eyes at Jane, mumbling to himself with a blank expression, "Seventeen milligrams per cubic centimeter was what the file had—five times the fatal dose, yet here you are still alive… Of course, how did I not think about that connection.""W-what are you… talking about?" Jane said as she stepped back. Something about the difficult-sounding medical words, the same ones she heard from her doctors, made her heart sink"Speak up, and to me," Miss Mary stepped in between the two.The man sighed and rubbed his eyes with an index and a thumb, his purple eyebags flexing with the friction. "I want the small Patterson to help me, as I believe her to be associated with Godeyes, and I'll provide—""Wha—" Marry spat, flabbergasted, "you can't be real. She's just a kid!""My evidence are absolute. She can be a valuable asset to my investigation.""Don't you dare call her an asset, you lifeless germ" Miss Mary growled, "and you'd have to take her out of my dead, cold, arms."A sense of warmth washed over Jane. Miss Mary would go this far for me? she asked herself, but before she felt any flattery by such remarks, she sensed a heavy shift in the air as the man raised three, tall, and bruised fingers."Three months," he said."Pardon?""I can get the church to extend their donations by three months. That is my offering.""I… I don't recall you having any catholic significance—just, how exactly are you planning to get that?""I am in no need to be holy," he reached his hand below the edge of his trench coat, revealing a polished, brass shield clipped to the dark fabric above his heart, "to be convincing," he flicked his nail against the PITTYFALL POLICE engraving and it dinged distinctly.An avalanche of silence buried the room. "J-Jane…?" Miss Mary said shakily and looked back with most horrifying of expressions: it was that of a pitiful implore.Jane shook her head almost immediately and hid behind the desk. Her heartbeats were banging at her ribcage."I... I d-don't remember any… anything!" Jane managed, and she was mostly truthful. That memory that had splashed in her mind not an hour ago was useless compared to the years she had lost. She still had no idea who her parents were, where she used to live, or how she lost the sight of her right eye."I will help you remember," the man said with ease, as if what he was saying was the easiest thing in the world."Jane, dear…" Miss Mary began, her voice soothing, yet wavering, "I'm with you here—really! But without the church's support, we'll be out of food in less than a week."Nope. Nope. Nope. Not happening. Godeyes? Police? Jane wanted none of that. Oh, how she we wished to read her favorite books at this moment, far away in the peaceful library. She would be a good girl this time. She wouldn't complain. And she wouldn't open that wretched, wretched, WRETCHED diary ever again. This was all its fault. It had to be."I promise you," Miss Mary continued, her desperate voice ripping apart Jane from the inside, "I'll find another donor if it's the last thing I'll do, and as soon as that happens, you won't be in need to help this schmuck anymore!"Jane felt her determination faltering. It wasn't like she didn't want to help Miss Mary, it was that she was scared. But her desire to payback Miss Mary for all of what she had done was almost as strong."Jane…? …I see," Miss Mary said, and Jane heard her turn around.Smacking her forehead, Jane pushed herself onto the light and away from the concealment of the desk. She kept her head low, her one functional eye studying the extended shadows of the two adults before her. They were as still as ice. She waited a second, hoping for a miracle to happen. An angel full of pity. A demon that ends misery.Nothing.Jane wanted to cry, but she was out of tears for the day. She nodded her head and whispered, "I can do it," hoping the two might not hear her. Her hopes were dismissed quickly as Miss Mary's short shadow swooped in and engulfed Jane in a hug. Unlike the last one, though, this was dry. No warmth radiated from it."Seems like a deal," the man said simply."Thank you," Miss Mary said to Jane's ear. "Thank you," she repeated it, much deeply. … It was after classes when Jane had a sudden urge to go reading. Forget what happened, and read. She got in the library, and went to her favorite spot to continue reading We Bumble bees. But the book wasn't in its usual place, slotted between Steven Planet and The Crow House.Then it hit her. She had put it on the floor before she asked Mr. Angelo about a new book, and before she found that… diary. I ended up losing my favorite book today, We Bumble Bees, it said, but it didn't say how she lost it. She instantly assumed it was as a result of the scolding. She looked around and saw that Mr. Angelo was not behind his round desk, nor near any of the shelves.The book had disappeared even though Jane wasn't scolded or punished for anything. If we reconstruct the scene without Jane hiding in the bathroom, would she have been scolded to begin with? Was Miss Mary even mad at her in the first place?Jane sat on the cold floor, leaned against the uneven surface of the shelf, and brought her knees to her chest. She closed her eyes and thought deeply.Today, I got in trouble, the diary had written, and that did happen. Jane was caught red-handed in the crime scene. But when Miss Mary took the crayon out of Jane's hand, she wasn't angerly looking at her saying What a troublemaker. When she did look, she wasn't mad. It was strange, because only now was Jane able to understand that the expression Miss Mary had at that moment was of concern and politeness, of a person who was troubling someone, not being troubled.If that was the case, why did she ask Jane to come to her office? And as soon as the question came out of Jane's mind, a picture appeared in her head: a mountain of papers with pens and coffee mugs and headache-free-no-risks-involved pills scattered around it on a desktop. Mind helping me organize some papers later, dear? Miss Mary had asked. Of course. It felt like hours, was written in the diary, and that was because organizing that mess would've felt like hours.The diary and its foretelling entry was accurate beyond what Jane had imagined, but not to a full extent. It had nothing to do with the tall man nor his deal. It changed because Jane morphed the entry into something it wasn't. She morphed it into a nightmare, then attempted to escape from the nightmare, which had caused fate to punish her, causing things to diverge.But that was silly. Fate punishing a ten-or-so-year-old girl for being a little scared? No, Jane was clearly overthinking things. She made honest mistakes due to the unclarity and vagueness of the diary, and all it did was mess with her head.Disappointed that she hadn't found any ground-breaking discoveries, Jane took out The Crow House and began reading, speeding the clock forward in time.Later that day at night, Jane asked Mr. Angelo and found that he put the book in one of his drawers. Again, just a set of inconvenient misunderstandings. Nothing more. …The next day, Jane was having lunch at an empty table in the noisy cafeteria of the orphanage. She looked down at her half-finished serving of mashed potatoes, sinister-looking cabbage, and sludge of beans, as whatever was in her mouth squelched down with the force of her teeth. She swallowed. I thought cooked air was a joke, she thought, tempted to use her knife and fork to take piece of air and compare its taste to her food. If this was the so-called food Miss Mary spoke of, then maybe not having it would be a blessing. Then again, she was only using the food as an example. There were probably many other expenses that an orphanage required."Done eating, Patterson?" a craggy voice came from where her vision didn't work."Ueh!" Jane shrieked a strange voice and hopped a seat in the opposite direction.The man, the same policeman from yesterday, looked at Jane dully, as if he's been doing so for the past 20 minutes. He attempted to morph his lips in a shape of a smile, but it looked more like he needed to pee, "Nice to meet you too.""Miss Mary… wh-where is she?""Busy."Was she already searching for another donor?"What do you want… from me?" Jane asked gently. Without Miss Mary, she had no protection from the bear, and worst of all, she had no idea what the bear will do."You've been to the Oddmoor Psychiatric hospital, I presume."Jane nodded. She hated that place."Well," he stood up, "we'll go pay them a visit. Now follow me.""But, but, the doctors… they're—""We're not visiting the doctors. We're visiting someone else."Jane stood up and followed suit. The two got out of the main entrance, and beyond the rusty gate, where a black, sleek car stood by."Name's Connor, by the way. Some minutes, please?" the pastor said from behind him.The man stood up in a swift, strong motion and turned. "Yes, brother, of course," and so, the stranger walked away, and Jane's heart began to beat again.What was that all about… Something tugged her sweater."You wake," Alice said with an intrigued expression and leaned on Jane's shoulder."I… w-wasn't asleep.""Oh," Alice blushed a little, "I thought you were…" She coughed into the stub of her cast. "Have you seen my stick?""Your c-crutch?""Yeah, whatever it's called.""Uh," I didn't think how I would explain this to her! "so, I hid it b-below our bench…"Alice narrowed her eyes. "Why?"Jane played with her fingers and her head was steaming, "B-because I… didn't want anyone to tr-trip on it! Y-yeah! Let me just bring it over…"Alice let go of Jane and hopped to the bench."I can—""Nah, I want." She took out the bench with some difficulty, and rested on it.Alice lightly tapped Jane's leg through the long fabric of her skirt. "So, I just want to say thanks for what you did there." She looked up and smiled, a free and unchanged smile. Jane could see the walls of the castle Alice had built flickering away in the glimmer of her eyes.It was like a torch burning in her heart. It lit up a ruddy apartment that had long forgotten the warmth of light. Jane held her chest and dropped her gaze. She was unable to stop any tear from flowing."Jay-Jay? Are you okay?" Alice wiped the tears away with her chubby hand."I'm sorry," Jane hiccupped, "I'm really sorry…!"Alice frowned. "Why? What have you done to apologize?""I… I was th-the one who c-caused all your i-injuries… It's m-my fault!""Jay-Jay," Alice bonked her on the head, "think clearly. Why would you have caused all of it? That doesn't make sense…""But," Jane held the top of her pained head, "but," she couldn't say it. She couldn't bring up that that future was her doing. It was torture."Jay-Jay, I told you this before. I don't want your apology." Alice tried soothing Jane.It was like a lightbulb. That wasn't her rejecting my apology. She never blamed me once. She never hated me once. She never judged me once."I see now..." Jane said through sludgy sniffs.Alice sighed a sigh of relief. "Let's get outta'ere shall we?" She walked over a couple of steps then looked back. "You okay? Why not move?"Jane looked down at her shoes. "I don't know… I'm t-trying." It wasn't working. She tried again, and it was almost as if her legs were cut from her body, or that hands had them pinned down.Alice came over and pushed Jane from the back, and suddenly, her feet began working again. "There you go.""Thanks, Alice."The two left and had a couple of minutes before the van went back to the orphanage.They decided to spend those minutes looking at the clouds and interpret their looks.Both of them had the time of their life.

item.title: Jane Patterson and the Foretelling Diary
item.description: It was happening again.Jane Patterson opened her eyes.And what she saw was nothing but nothingness itself. Thick darkness veiled the surroundings from all directions, and only one entity stood center stage: a gleaming, red bathtub. She felt her chest shiver—the slightly painful type of shiver."H-hello…? Is… is anyone here?" she inquired, turning her head away from the tub and checking for any possible reaction. "I'm scared…" Her statement was only met by its own echo. Though the scenery wasn't unfamiliar, It still gave Jane the heebie-jeebies. It wasn't her fault the only dream she had was this abomination.Standing in the void amidst deafening silence was something, but being in the same space as that bathtub, was something else entirely. It stank with ominosity, as if knives and hammers swung all round it, or as if touching it would poison her to death, or simply hurt her. The fear was as much instinctive as it was reactional, yet, it wasn't logical, as she had no real reason to fear the tub. With no desire to walk up to it, Jane decided to walk away from it. She moved a good five-meters and turned back. The bathtub was as close as it was before she had moved. Of course, she thought. Nothing new.But suddenly, an idea struck her. Jane was a tiny kid, not that she liked that fact, and due to her height, she was never able to see what was in the bathtub from the distance it was in before. Coming closer to it was an idea out of the picture; out of the room; and out the house, but peeking at what was inside of it intrigued her. She took a long breath and raised her body atop her tippy-toes. Right at the distant end of the bathtub, she saw what looked to be deep, blue water, and the moment that water reflected in Jane's eyes, something squeezed her heart like a stress toy. Suddenly, there was no floor, and Jane was falling at high speed.It was only then, when she truly opened her eye. … Jane jolted awake, her heart racing. The left side of her chin and the shoulder below it were completely damp in drool, likewise the open book in her lap. One of the lines was drenched, but barely readable: Big Bee wants justice. Big Bee wants honey.She looked around in a daze, seeing towers of bookshelves and orange stars made of glass. Did I sleep the entire night? A glimpse at the clock above the broad double-doors showed that the small, chunky hand pointed at IV and the tall, thin one between XI and XII. She pondered for a second as her brain ran calculations. Six… no, no… When there is an I to the left, you take one away… so four in the morning. There was plenty of time before the bell rang and the day began."Morning there, missy," an old man said, causing Jane to jump and fall on her side. The man croaked a chuckle and bent over his round desk, smiling to her. "You snored like a hummingbird," he said, his gentle eyes unassuming above his round spectacles."G-good morning… to… too, Mr. Angelo," she said, her mind attempting to imagine what a hummingbird was before she could imagine it snoring. Mr. Angelo drew back and disappeared from Jane's vision. It was best if she went back to her reading, but she wasn't that delighted to go through the book for the umpteenth time. She thought for a moment, and realized a possible solution, though it required her to use her voice again… She shivered, but stood up nevertheless, wiping away the drool off her face. She left her book at the floor, making a mental note to return to it later."Um, Mr. Angelo…" she mumbled, only the top half of her pale, ghostly face, half-obscured by black hair, visible above the desktop, "Is… is there… is there…" She was taken back by the fact that Mr. Angelo was reading his book upside down. "Wh-why… read it that way?"He looked at the book, back at Jane, then smiled, "Why not?"Mr. Angelo was always strange, Jane reminded herself. Back on topic, "I was… gonna ask. Is there anything you recommend?""Of course," he said with enthusiastic body language, "everything!""How about… um… something more specific?" Jane was not about read everything, unless that was a book on its own. She looked down for a moment, her pink slippers looked back at her with googly eyes. "Something… nice?" she said, looking up cautiously to check Mr. Angelo's expression. His optics drilled into her with a thoughtful look. She looked away again. "Y-you know… Like all the other ones I read."He sighed, "Unfortunately, you've read all those books." Jane heard noises of thumps and papers moving. "But how about this." She looked up and found Mr. Angelo holding up a book with the title The Adventures of Sherlock Holmes written above, and By A. Conan Doyle written below it. She knew this one. "It has… murder in it," she said."It's a fine book. Good puzzles and all.""I do not… like it…""It's a little difficult, sure, but—""I don't want to.""You haven't given it a try. If only you—""No!" she said in Mr. Angelo's face with loud enough volume to leave a trail of reverberation in the room. Upon realizing her ill-manners, Jane covered her mouth and looked down in shame. "I'm sorry," she whimpered."You'll eventually run out, you know," Mr. Angelo said with a warm, but firm, voice. "You'll eventually be left with nothing but the books you hate, and what will you do then?"Jane stayed silent at that. Part of her regretted asking Mr. Angelo in the first place.Mr. Angelo took a deep inhale, then a long exhale. From the corner of her watery eye, Jane saw his hand rise and point in a direction behind her. "You'll find a new batch of books below Saint Mathew's window. Maybe something there will catch your attention."Jane lifted her head slowly. Mr. Angelo returned to his usual smile, but she couldn't help but feel that there was a hint of trouble in his eyes. It was probably her that troubled him. At the very least, she would need to keep her manners in place."Thank you," she said with a nod, and he nodded too, before returning to his upside down study. … Jane found herself in a narrow passage between the far wall of the library and a soaring bookshelf opposite to it. High above, four stained windows washed the library with color—mainly a soft hue of red, which brought a feeling of tension and religious significance.Like how Mr. Angelo said, there was a pile of unorganized books below one of the windows, most likely Matthew's. She approached the possible pile of time-devouring entertainment and began her search on the floor. From books of languages Jane didn't understand, to books of topics she had no interest in. The pile was starting to dwindle when Jane found something fascinating: an untitled, leather-bound notebook. Who would donate their own notebook? Jane thought as she opened the cover to check its content. Jane Patterson… Like, Me Patterson? she thought, trying to comprehend what she was seeing. Such a bizarre coincidence to find a diary with the exact same name as Jane. The time recorded was also this year. Now much more intrigued, Jane flipped a page and commenced her reading. Dear diary, Today, a new year rolls in, and it also happens to be the one year anniversary of my stay at the Pittyfall House of Children as a foundling. My memory hasn't improved one bit. I still don't remember nine years of my life. I still don't remember who's my mom or my dad. I still don't remember anything. Jane's jaw was on the floor. I don't understand, her brain called out as all the logic units went out of commission. This month-old entry recorded what seemed to be an exact parallel of what Jane had felt that exact day. But that was absurd. There had to be an explanation for this. Jane flipped to another page and continued reading, her eyes mere centimeters away from the paper. Good morning diary, Alice Danger found some firecrackers, and from the sounds of the screams, it looks like she's terrorizing the other kids with it. Thankfully, she doesn't come to the library. I found a nice book called We Bumble Bees. It's so fun. I love Big Bee! No, no, no! her head was spinning, and her face was glued to the pages of the diary, so much so that it looked like the notebook was eating her. It felt like she was chasing her own tail, trying to find something besides the obvious. Her heart froze in time. It was difficult to breath, and though the room was warm and cozy, Jane was shivering. From a sitting pose, she fell back down and the hair that covered the right side of her face fell away, revealing a silver eye with an old gash going through it. It was a stark contrast to the eye next to it, which was dark. Her lips were cautious as they shaped each syllable of the words from today's entry. Good evening diary, Today, I got in trouble and ended up in the director's office. It felt like hours in there, and I ended up losing my favorite book today, We Bumble Bees. I'm so sad… The diary slipped out of Jane's hands and fell on her face. She made no attempt to pick it up, or any attempt to move for that matter. She simply laid down in silence, foolishly attempting to process what she had just read. Hours passed while she was in her diseased pose, not asleep, but fully awake.Were the doctors right when they said I've lost my mind? Or did this diary just predict the future? She thought over the entry: So I'll be in trouble, be scolded and punished for hours, and then my favorite book will be taken? This is the worst! But that was only if the diary is not some prank, which Jane believed it to be, as there was no other explanation.A bell rang in the distance, and though it was typically the most annoying thing to hear in the world, when its so far that it no longer scrapped your ears, it was surprisingly soothing. Jane wanted to sleep so badly, her conscious mushy and soft, slipping away into dream land. But Jane knew what she had in dream land. It was better to not doze off. As she lifted her back, the diary fell away. She pondered momentarily about what she would do with it, but she realized she didn't want to do anything with it. She wanted it to leave her mind, as it was already cluttered. She took the notebook and shoved it in the narrow space between the shelf and the floor. Out of sight, out of mind. When she walked back, she found that Mr. Angelo was not behind the round desk. … Jane was happy that her seat was located at the far corner of the classroom. If that diary had a sliver of accuracy, it would be favorable if Jane was hidden, especially when considering how well her gray attire camouflaged her amidst the colorless light surging through the windows from gloomy clouds.The yapping and barking of children were silenced instantly at the loud yank of the classroom door. A short, plump woman with ginger hair came in quickly, speaking in a professional let's-get-over-with-it tone."Morning children.""Good morning, Miss Mary Patterson," everyone said in unharmonized unison. It was always strange hearing that surname. A mother? No, just a staff member who gave their surname to a child who didn't remember theirs.With speed and elegance, she wrote the title Psalm 34:4 on the chalkboard and spoke to the children as if she had an eye on the back of her head. "Desmos, stop eating the paper. You will choke. Louis, stop laughing at Desmos and tell your sister to focus on the subject. Art class can wait. And Alice," she turned around and looked down at the blond-haired girl glaring at the kid next to her, "it's rude to stare. You're gonna make Dean uncomfortable," Alice made a huffing noise before she looked away dramatically.Looks normal… Jane assured herself. If something bad were to happen, it wasn't now for sure. As the class went on, Jane decided to immerse herself with the view outside. Dead trees and mud. That was all what the rusted bars had enclosed, that and the grimy Jesus statue in the middle. But behind those bars, Jane saw someone. A tall figure next to a sleek, black car. It was then when the classroom door opened once more. Jane shifted her attention to it and found Mr. Angelo."Miss Director," he said with unease and began whispering to her."Christ…" She clicked her tongue and went back to writing on the board, "Tell him the only thing waiting for him here is a beating."Mr. Angelo nodded and exited the room. Not a blink of an eye later, Jane found him walking up to the tall man behind the bars. That was fast… she thought and blamed her consciousness for dozing off. A small exchange later, and the tall man cupped his hands over his mouth and yelled."Hey, honey. Do not make me get a warrant." All kids crooked their heads towards the monotone, yet sarcastic, voice.Miss Mary opened one of the windows with a surprisingly strong motion. "I'll make you, jackass." She closed it and pulled the curtains down. Everyone kept staring at her. "Back to class—and, you didn't hear me cuss." That was met with moans and groans of disappointment.Well, that was not normal, Jane thought, but it wasn't her causing trouble, or being scolded for hours, or having her favorite book taken. Not normal, but good so far…And it was good all the way through, except for the end: class had concluded and kids were scattering when Miss Mary came over to Jane's table. No trouble… No trouble… she repeated in her head. "Mind helping me organize some papers later, dear? I just have a lot on my plate lately," she said.Jane barely heard her over the thumping of her heart. She nodded. As long as trouble was off-frame. She nodded obediently, and received Miss Mary's rough hand as it ruffled her hair. … Jane spent her free time like a pray in the wild, keeping her best to stay safe. Would the person she had just bumped into attack her and make a fuss out of it? No, but they did say she looked like an ugly ghost—it was an upper classmate. Would the floor that had just creaked under her feet break and cause her to go to detention? No, but it did scare the living daylight out of her. Was Mr. Carl about to grab Jane and beat her like he always did with the other naughty children? No, but he did jabber about Jane's tousled hair and her untidy clothes.This diary and its entry were getting to Jane too much. It was probably just a prank. An unfunny and cruel one. She was not about to let a stack of papers get the best of her. Her anger forged her motivation, and she stomped her way through the halls. Her goal: somewhere quiet, aka the backyard.As she reached last corner, Dean passed her, flashing a bright smile. It was only too late when she had realized that he actually said Hello to her. "Oh—um, h-hi, there…" she said, but he was way too far to hear her. Dean was one of the few kids Jane considered to be a good apple, and here she was ignoring him. Embarrassment swirled in her head as it slumped down. She only deserved to look at the floor from now on.After a turn, she was seeing surging light from the backdoor making the wood below her brighter each step. It was then when something rolled onto Jane's shoes: a green crayon. She picked it up and read the cutoff text Starlight Color Works (SPECIAL EDIT- in her mind. Nothing out of the ordinary, she thought and a rustle scuttled before her. She looked up, and what she saw there made her heart squelch. It was Alice. Her face was covered in green, and she was out of breath."N-no trouble, please…" Jane trembled.Alice's eyes seemed unfocused, but she saw them glance to the right for a split-second. That was where Jane could not see. She turned her head and faced the worst possible thing to see.Mary Patterson's a BITCH! was written on the adjacent wall with a radiant green color. The same crayon that Jane was holding… Immediately, she snapped her head back at Alice, but she had already ran far in the backyard. In a moment of complete panic, Jane wound up her hand and shoulder, ready to throw the crayon into the next continent if necessary. But suddenly, a rough hand squeezed hers, taking the crayon from it. Though Jane knew who that hand belonged to, she was still aghast when the face of Mary Patterson drew in front of her."What a troublemaker," Miss Mary mumbled, her eyes at the crayon.Jane wasn't even worth to be looked down upon. "N-no… It… I…" she shrilled, attempting to explain herself and failing miserably.Miss Mary looked at Jane suddenly and her expression changed in a way Jane didn't understand. "Wait in my office," she said before leaving.Jane stood still for a while, unsure whether to cry or fall down and pretend to die. She didn't want to be scolded by Miss Mary. She respected her, but now that she knew that diary was correct—that it predicted the truth, however painful that truth was, Jane didn't see how she could escape the scolding. … The familiar room felt suffocating.Jane sat on a rickety wooden chair before a desk with a huge pile of papers, a cup of coffee with Don't You Miss Sunday Services! written on it, and a bunch of pill packs with the title Headache Free - NO RISKS and a picture of a pretty lady with a set of blinding teeth set beside it. She felt her body with five times its typical weight, as if gravity was her enemy. Her mind was a collection of staircases and pathways that all lead to the image of how Jane would be scolded—insulted—humiliated. It felt like hours in there, the diary had said, and Jane was living those hours at the moment. Her heart was so jammed in her throat, she felt she would throw up at any point. It all felt sickening.In a minute or two, Jane would have to face Miss Mary's fury for what she had not done, and explaining herself, with her clumsy tongue and such damning evidence against her, felt useless. She was trapped, and she desired to escape so badly. Run out the room and hide somewhere, she thought to herself. Anywhere.The sound of a footstep suddenly slipped from below the door behind her, which did nothing but made her anxiety reach boiling point. Her main escape route was now blocked.As if her body moved on its own, Jane jumped off the chair and zipped to the next best thing: the office private bathroom. She would hide there until Miss Mary left, then sneakily leave after. It was no perfect plan, but it was a plan. Jane slammed her small body against the door as she missed to catch the handle multiple times. At last, she grasped it, swung the door, shoved herself in, and closed it behind her, making sure to click the lock. She glued her left ear against the door and did her best to keep her breathing down.A distant door swung open with a creak. Steps thudded vibrations across the floor. Then, a pause."She didn't come, huh…" Jane heard Miss Mary's muffle.Rat-tat, a postmen-like knock punched the air."In," Miss Mary said.Another creak later, Jane heard that familiar monotone voice once more."Got my warrant," the motionless voice said."Good," she said out of her teeth, "what's the occasion?"Jane turned around, discouraged by eavesdropping on Miss Mary when she was this heated. She studied the bathroom she was in as a distraction. A cracked mirror cabinet, an orange, curtained window emanating the fuzzy light of the early afternoon, and one, gleaming, red bathtub.A shiver jolted up Jane's spine and activated something in her head. Something that dragged her out of her body and somewhere far away, sometime far off. … Jane saw a bathroom—a cramped, old one. But not the same one she had just been in. A different one. It reeked of a medicinal smell, sharp and bitter.A dream? she thought, but it was clear she had no control over the body she possessed. This was a memory. A memory that was surging through a crack on the dam of her head.Besides seeing and smelling, she also felt things—intangible things. She felt oppressed and trapped. She felt exhausted and sickened. She felt something rattle at her wrist. It was a chain. She was attached to the faucet of the red bathtub that was full of blue water. She also sensed her clothes fully drenched in that same water. From the mess on the tiled floor, it looked like she had dragged herself out of the tub by sheer force.But atop all those feelings, there was one that washed everything. It was a searing, pulsating pain throbbing in her head. Unbelievably bad, to the point that moving her eyes caused it to intensify greatly.What a miserable place. What a miserable life.She suddenly heard that someone was approaching and every cell of her body screamed in terror.The door behind her screeched slowly, and he walked in. … Jane opened her eye, both of her hands holding her head. It was not hurting—it never did. She breathed deeply, her body shivering. She got out before she understood who he was, but she was very glad. She didn't want to see what was there, and now, she didn't want to stay here. She had to leave.She took one glance at the red shell of the tub before unlocking the door and exiting, her eyes downcast and mouth open. Not a dream, but a memory, she thought to herself."Jane?" Miss Mary said in disbelief, a letter in her hand.Right. Jane was trying to hide. She looked up at her, then to the tall man besides hers, with his purple eyebags and dead fish expression, before she broke down and sobbed. There was much inside of her, from her fear of being scolded, to that awful memory she had just seen. It was like she was trying to speak those feelings, but the words came out as cries and whimpers instead of eligible syllables.Miss Mary rushed in to embrace her. "Dear, what happened?" She sounded hoarse. "Why are you crying?"Jane didn't answer. She didn't know how. So she cried for a while until the tears dried up and she was left with only sniffles. One positive thing that came out of this was that these cries seemed to have calmed Miss Mary down, because it didn't look like she was mad at Jane anymore."Oh, taking care of your little dumplings must be hard…" the tall man said, "Now that the orphanage is closing, I believe the difficulty would be bumped into impossible.""C-closing?" Jane said through sniffles, "What does he mean?" she looked at Miss Mary with reddened eyes."It's…" she looked away, "It's…""Church no longer wants to support the orphans with donations," the man interjected, "I'm sure they have a real good reason for that.""And they do!" Miss Mary said confidently, "I'm sure they do…" her voice trailed off."Of course there is. It's called Godeyes. The cult responsible for the many recent goofy activities within the church.""You do not know for sure," she said and turned with a pointed finger."Of course I don't know for sure, dummy. If I did, I would've put them all in jail already. It's just a matter of time."Jane was beginning to lose the topic, but one thing concerned her above all else. "I-is the orphanage really closing?"Miss Mary turned to her, "Don't worry, Jane, I'll… I'll find—""Pardon me," the man interrupted and stepped forth between the two, "Jane? Like, the kid we found in the streets a year ago?" He looked at Jane curiously. "Right, Jane Patterson…" He then shifted into a more deep and thoughtful look."Mind shoving aside?" Miss Mary told him.He moved with no comments, keeping that same look."Look, I'll find a new donor as fast I can," Miss Mary said, "You do not worry—""Of course," the man interrupted once again, "how could I have missed this…""What is it now?" Miss Mary said, her patience running thin and her fist clenching tighter than ever."Honey, I believe we can strike quite a beneficial deal," he said and came over to Jane, "A deal that will surely interest you." Though he was talking while looking at Jane, he seemed more focused on something beyond her.Jane eyed Miss Mary with confusion and dread as she only imagined what his deal would be."What does your deal entail?" Miss Mary inquired, her eyes hostile.The man kept his eyes at Jane, mumbling to himself with a blank expression, "Seventeen milligrams per cubic centimeter was what the file had—five times the fatal dose, yet here you are still alive… Of course, how did I not think about that connection.""W-what are you… talking about?" Jane said as she stepped back. Something about the difficult-sounding medical words, the same ones she heard from her doctors, made her heart sink"Speak up, and to me," Miss Mary stepped in between the two.The man sighed and rubbed his eyes with an index and a thumb, his purple eyebags flexing with the friction. "I want the small Patterson to help me, as I believe her to be associated with Godeyes, and I'll provide—""Wha—" Marry spat, flabbergasted, "you can't be real. She's just a kid!""My evidence are absolute. She can be a valuable asset to my investigation.""Don't you dare call her an asset, you lifeless germ" Miss Mary growled, "and you'd have to take her out of my dead, cold, arms."A sense of warmth washed over Jane. Miss Mary would go this far for me? she asked herself, but before she felt any flattery by such remarks, she sensed a heavy shift in the air as the man raised three, tall, and bruised fingers."Three months," he said."Pardon?""I can get the church to extend their donations by three months. That is my offering.""I… I don't recall you having any catholic significance—just, how exactly are you planning to get that?""I am in no need to be holy," he reached his hand below the edge of his trench coat, revealing a polished, brass shield clipped to the dark fabric above his heart, "to be convincing," he flicked his nail against the PITTYFALL POLICE engraving and it dinged distinctly.An avalanche of silence buried the room. "J-Jane…?" Miss Mary said shakily and looked back with most horrifying of expressions: it was that of a pitiful implore.Jane shook her head almost immediately and hid behind the desk. Her heartbeats were banging at her ribcage."I... I d-don't remember any… anything!" Jane managed, and she was mostly truthful. That memory that had splashed in her mind not an hour ago was useless compared to the years she had lost. She still had no idea who her parents were, where she used to live, or how she lost the sight of her right eye."I will help you remember," the man said with ease, as if what he was saying was the easiest thing in the world."Jane, dear…" Miss Mary began, her voice soothing, yet wavering, "I'm with you here—really! But without the church's support, we'll be out of food in less than a week."Nope. Nope. Nope. Not happening. Godeyes? Police? Jane wanted none of that. Oh, how she we wished to read her favorite books at this moment, far away in the peaceful library. She would be a good girl this time. She wouldn't complain. And she wouldn't open that wretched, wretched, WRETCHED diary ever again. This was all its fault. It had to be."I promise you," Miss Mary continued, her desperate voice ripping apart Jane from the inside, "I'll find another donor if it's the last thing I'll do, and as soon as that happens, you won't be in need to help this schmuck anymore!"Jane felt her determination faltering. It wasn't like she didn't want to help Miss Mary, it was that she was scared. But her desire to payback Miss Mary for all of what she had done was almost as strong."Jane…? …I see," Miss Mary said, and Jane heard her turn around.Smacking her forehead, Jane pushed herself onto the light and away from the concealment of the desk. She kept her head low, her one functional eye studying the extended shadows of the two adults before her. They were as still as ice. She waited a second, hoping for a miracle to happen. An angel full of pity. A demon that ends misery.Nothing.Jane wanted to cry, but she was out of tears for the day. She nodded her head and whispered, "I can do it," hoping the two might not hear her. Her hopes were dismissed quickly as Miss Mary's short shadow swooped in and engulfed Jane in a hug. Unlike the last one, though, this was dry. No warmth radiated from it."Seems like a deal," the man said simply."Thank you," Miss Mary said to Jane's ear. "Thank you," she repeated it, much deeply. … It was after classes when Jane had a sudden urge to go reading. Forget what happened, and read. She got in the library, and went to her favorite spot to continue reading We Bumble bees. But the book wasn't in its usual place, slotted between Steven Planet and The Crow House.Then it hit her. She had put it on the floor before she asked Mr. Angelo about a new book, and before she found that… diary. I ended up losing my favorite book today, We Bumble Bees, it said, but it didn't say how she lost it. She instantly assumed it was as a result of the scolding. She looked around and saw that Mr. Angelo was not behind his round desk, nor near any of the shelves.The book had disappeared even though Jane wasn't scolded or punished for anything. If we reconstruct the scene without Jane hiding in the bathroom, would she have been scolded to begin with? Was Miss Mary even mad at her in the first place?Jane sat on the cold floor, leaned against the uneven surface of the shelf, and brought her knees to her chest. She closed her eyes and thought deeply.Today, I got in trouble, the diary had written, and that did happen. Jane was caught red-handed in the crime scene. But when Miss Mary took the crayon out of Jane's hand, she wasn't angerly looking at her saying What a troublemaker. When she did look, she wasn't mad. It was strange, because only now was Jane able to understand that the expression Miss Mary had at that moment was of concern and politeness, of a person who was troubling someone, not being troubled.If that was the case, why did she ask Jane to come to her office? And as soon as the question came out of Jane's mind, a picture appeared in her head: a mountain of papers with pens and coffee mugs and headache-free-no-risks-involved pills scattered around it on a desktop. This was too much."Thanks for telling me," Miss Mary's rough hand patted Jane, "and sorry I doubted you—even for a second."Jane nodded and walked back fast to her place near Alice.Her heart was beating so hard, she was surprised she didn't die right then and there from a heart attack. As if far as she was concerned, Alice didn't talk to her, and the class continued as usual—though, with a lot of murmuring mixed in.It was finally when she felt that her body parts had calmed down, Jane began taking in her surroundings once more. It must've been the end of the class, because most kids were gone except the few who was still talking and peeking at Jane. She got out of the bench and a deep voice rumbled behind her."I think this belongs to you," the man said.Jane turned and found her own painting from before. A vase with a shattered eye. She took it and looked at the man who had it in his hands. He wore a black shirt under a slick suit. A blue cross medallion hanged from his neck.It was a stranger.He smiled, his void eyes sedate and his hairless brows arched. "You must be Jane Patterson.""Y-yeah…" She remembered, from just a few days ago: Showed it a dear friend of a mine, and he was thrilled! "You g-got this from Miss D-Dervla…?"The man nodded, "She's quite enthusiastic about this stuff and shows me pieces all the time. I had a visit planned here already, so I thought come by and personally give it to you."But why go through the effort?He kneeled and brought his eyes to Jane's level. "I hear today's theme is sin?" his eyes narrowed, and his apparent interest peaked. "Tell me, what do you believe to be the best way to cleanse the sin?"Jane thought about her sin: the diary, her tampering with the future, and the broken bones in Alice. "You… w-work hard to m-make for it?""No, child, it's not enough. You must erase its existence. You see," The man began stretching his ring-riddled hand towards Jane, "If I don't know," Jane wanted to move away, but she couldn't, "and if you don't know," his words were like a hypnotizing ocean, "and if everyone doesn't know," the man's hand brushed aside the hair hiding Jane's silver eye, and his face flickered with ecstasy, "the no one knows!""Brother Oswald…? Some minutes, please?" the pastor said from behind him.The man stood up in a swift, strong motion and turned. "Yes, brother, of course," and so, the stranger walked away, and Jane's heart began to beat again.What was that all about… Something tugged her sweater."You wake," Alice said with an intrigued expression and leaned on Jane's shoulder."I… w-wasn't asleep.""Oh," Alice blushed a little, "I thought you were…" She coughed into the stub of her cast. "Have you seen my stick?""Your c-crutch?""Yeah, whatever it's called.""Uh," I didn't think how I would explain this to her! "so, I hid it b-below our bench…"Alice narrowed her eyes. "Why?"Jane played with her fingers and her head was steaming, "B-because I… didn't want anyone to tr-trip on it! Y-yeah! Let me just bring it over…"Alice let go of Jane and hopped to the bench."I can—""Nah, I want." She took out the bench with some difficulty, and rested on it.Alice lightly tapped Jane's leg through the long fabric of her skirt. "So, I just want to say thanks for what you did there." She looked up and smiled, a free and unchanged smile. Jane could see the walls of the castle Alice had built flickering away in the glimmer of her eyes.It was like a torch burning in her heart. It lit up a ruddy apartment that had long forgotten the warmth of light. Jane held her chest and dropped her gaze. She was unable to stop any tear from flowing."Jay-Jay? Are you okay?" Alice wiped the tears away with her chubby hand."I'm sorry," Jane hiccupped, "I'm really sorry…!"Alice frowned. "Why? What have you done to apologize?""I… I was th-the one who c-caused all your i-injuries… It's m-my fault!""Jay-Jay," Alice bonked her on the head, "think clearly. Why would you have caused all of it? That doesn't make sense…""But," Jane held the top of her pained head, "but," she couldn't say it. She couldn't bring up that that future was her doing. It was torture."Jay-Jay, I told you this before. I don't want your apology." Alice tried soothing Jane.It was like a lightbulb. That wasn't her rejecting my apology. She never blamed me once. She never hated me once. She never judged me once."I see now..." Jane said through sludgy sniffs.Alice sighed a sigh of relief. "Let's get outta'ere shall we?" She walked over a couple of steps then looked back. "You okay? Why not move?"Jane looked down at her shoes. "I don't know… I'm t-trying." It wasn't working. She tried again, and it was almost as if her legs were cut from her body, or that hands had them pinned down.Alice came over and pushed Jane from the back, and suddenly, her feet began working again. "There you go.""Thanks, Alice."The two left and had a couple of minutes before the van went back to the orphanage.They decided to spend those minutes looking at the clouds and interpret their looks.Both of them had the time of their life.
